discussion.author: thery
discussion.comment:
Should we also generalize ler_psqrt?
````coq
Lemma ler_psqrt : {in @Num.nneg R &, {mono sqrt : a b / a <= b}}.
Proof.
apply: le_mono_in => x y x_gt0 y_gt0.
rewrite !lt_neqAle => /andP[neq_xy le_xy].
by rewrite ler_wsqrtr // eqr_sqrt // neq_xy.
Qed. 

Lemma ler_sqrt a b : 0 <= b -> (sqrt a <= sqrt b) = (a <= b).
Proof.
move=> b_ge0; have [a_le0|a_gt0] := ler0P a; last first.
  by rewrite ler_psqrt // nnegrE ltW.
by rewrite ler0_sqrtr // sqrtr_ge0 (le_trans a_le0).
Qed.
````

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment:
Thanks for your contribution! Some of these lemmas may indeed be useful. However, I wonder whether we really want to add all of them. Indeed, some rewritings can be obtained with patterns or the mechanism in [ssrAC](https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/blob/master/mathcomp/ssreflect/ssrAC.v) as examplified below. Could you remove those lemmas from your pull request? (I guess the remaining lemmas should be the `___lemma` in https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/issues/643 but I haven't thoroughly checked)

```Coq
From mathcomp Require Import ssreflect ssrfun ssrbool ssrnat bigop ssrAC.

Lemma ex1 m n p : (m + n) + p = (n + m) + p.
Proof. by rewrite [X in X + _]addnC. Qed.

Lemma ex2 m n p : (m + n) + p = (n + p) + m.
Proof. by rewrite (ACl (2*3*1))/=. Qed.

Lemma ex3 m n p : m + (n + p) = p + (m + n).
Proof. by rewrite (AC (1*2) (3*(1*2)))/=. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
What's the motivation for this renaming? I have no opinion about it, but in any case it should come with a deprecation notation to help users adapt to the change:
```suggestion
Lemma addnCAl m n p: m + n + p = n + (p + m).
Proof. by rewrite (addnC m) addnC addnCA. Qed.

#[deprecated(since="mathcomp 1.17.0, note="use addnCAl instead"")]
Notation addnACl := addnCAl.
```

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
While this change seems useful in practice, I have two remarks:
- I think that `order_scope` should not be opened unless you are reasoning about abstract order instances.
- Opening `ring_scope` after `order_scope` seems better in general since it should give precedence to the notations in `ring_scope` in parsing:
  > If a notation is defined in multiple scopes, Coq uses the interpretation from the most recently opened notation scope or declared lonely notation.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment:
>     * I think that `order_scope` should not be opened unless you are reasoning about abstract order instances.
> 
>     * Opening `ring_scope` after `order_scope` seems better in general since it should give precedence to the notations in `ring_scope` in parsing:
>       > If a notation is defined in multiple scopes, Coq uses the interpretation from the most recently opened notation scope or declared lonely notation.

But then , how would you handle two concrete orders, one being on some numDomainType but not the other?

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
> But then, how would you handle two concrete orders, one being on some numDomainType but not the other?

In that case, I would open only `ring_scope` and explicitly write `%O` (or another scope delimiter if applicable) for the other.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: That sounds pretty inconvenient, why shouldn't we open `order_scope`? Is there something bad with having a generic `_ <= _` notation for all porder types? or some other reason?

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment:
@pi8027 I have given a bit more though to this and I realize maybe I'm just messing something up with my displays. Here is my use case:
* orders on `numDomainType` have a notation on `ring_display` that  parses and prints as `(_ <= _)%R`
* in Analysis (c.f. [constructive_ereal.v](https://github.com/math-comp/analysis/blob/master/theories/constructive_ereal.v)), the extended reals have a notation on `ereal_display` that also parses and prints as `(_ <= _)%E`

Maybe we should just reuse `ring_display` in `constructive_ereal.v` as we don't really want the display to differ from the one of `ring_display` after all? Doing this, I wouldn't have to open `order_scope` (or put `%E` scope annotations everywhere) but only `ring_scope` in my usecase.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: @proux01 From my superficial understanding, it is safer to have both `ring_display` (resp. `ring_scope`) and `ereal_display` (resp. `ereal_scope`). But `constructive_ereal.v` seems to lack specialized notations for `bottom` and `top` (and thus both `bottom` and `GRing.zero` are printed as `0`?). What about redefining `+oo` and `-oo` as such?

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment:
> `constructive_ereal.v` seems to lack specialized notations for `bottom` and `top` (and thus both `bottom` and `GRing.zero` are printed as `0`?). What about redefining `+oo` and `-oo` as such?

I agree, thanks for pointing this out.

> @proux01 From my superficial understanding, it is safer to have both ring_display (resp. ring_scope) and ereal_display (resp. ereal_scope).

Well, what's the point of having two different displays with the same... display? When writing pen and paper proofs I write `_ <= _` both for reals and extended reals, I would find it nice if I didn't need to change one to `(_ <= _)%R` or `(_ <= _)%E` when formalizing.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
> > @proux01 From my superficial understanding, it is safer to have both ring_display (resp. ring_scope) and ereal_display (resp. ereal_scope).
> 
> Well, what's the point of having two different displays with the same... display? When writing pen and paper proofs I write `_ <= _` both for reals and extended reals, I would find it nice if I didn't need to change one to `(_ <= _)%R` or `(_ <= _)%E` when formalizing.

I think that mixing `(_ <= _)%R` and `(_ <= _)%E` in printing is potential pitfall, although I don't have any concrete example.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: Could you elaborate on your idea? I just don't grasp it unfortunately.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: Sure. `(x%:E <= y%:E)%E` should be convertible with `(x <= y)%R`, but we have to unfold `Order.le` in the first term to see this fact. IIUC, keyed matching does not unfold the head symbol to see this kind of fact (it checks whether the arguments are respectively convertible after finding a candidate subterm based on the head symbol). So it seems that ssr tactics may not find the right subterm you expect, unless we have a clear distinction between these two things.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: To be clear, I'm not against the changes introduced by this PR, but saying that there is a discipline in the use of displays, notation scopes, etc. We can open an issue on the analysis repo and continue the discussion.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
proux01
discussion.comment:
> @pi8027 I agree we should have a more general discussion

I added the point to the agenda of the next Analysis meeting (extended reals are still there currently)

> I would be more aggressive and add `\bot` and `\top` and remove `0` and `1` from `order_scope`, and risk breaking compat and add declarations in the few (I expect) places where it's really necessary.

Indeed, done that

> We could also add unscoped `0%O` and `1%O` parsing only notations,

Done, this doesn't work with Coq 8.13 and 8.14 (apparently something got fixed/improved in 8.15), so I think this is a good time to drop support for 8.13 and 8.14, if we agree CI is now green.

> maybe we can even hack the display to trigger a deprecation warning?

Didn't manage to get anything along this line but since the notation is parsing only, the printing should already be an indice that something changed (beside it doesn't seem to be much used (apparently only mczify in the CI)).

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: Just in case, I opened a PR to fix mczify math-comp/mczify#46.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: Thanks, no hurry, that'll only be actually required when we'll remove the new deprecated `0%O` and `1%O` notations.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma big_if I r (P Q : pred I) F G :
  \big[*%M/1]_(i <- r | P i) (if Q i then F i else G i) =
    \big[*%M/1]_(i <- r | P i && Q i) F i *
    \big[*%M/1]_(i <- r | P i && ~~ Q i) G i.
Proof.
rewrite (bigID Q); congr (_ * _); apply: eq_bigr => i /andP[_].
  by move=> ->.
by move=> /negPf ->.
Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma bigA_distr (R : Type) (zero one : R) (mul : Monoid.mul_law zero)
  (add : Monoid.add_law zero mul) (I : finType) (F G : I -> R) :
  \big[mul/one]_i add (F i) (G i) =
  \big[add/zero]_(J in {set I}) \big[mul/one]_i (if i \in J then F i else G i).
Proof.
under eq_bigr => i _ do rewrite -(big_bool _ (fun b => if b then F i else G i)).
rewrite bigA_distr_bigA.
set f := fun J : {set I} => val J.
transitivity (\big[add/zero]_(f0 in (imset f (mem setT)))
                \big[mul/one]_i (if f0 i then F i else G i)).
  suff <-: setT = imset f (mem setT) by apply: congr_big=>// i; rewrite in_setT.
  apply/esym/eqP; rewrite -subTset; apply/subsetP => b _.
  by apply/imsetP; exists (FinSet b).
rewrite big_imset; last by case=> g; case=> h _ _; rewrite /f => /= ->.
apply: congr_big => //; case=> g; first exact: in_setT.
move=> _; apply: eq_bigr => i _; congr (if _ then _ else _).
by rewrite SetDef.pred_of_setE.
Qed.
```

Sure... but [`Gauss`](https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/blob/547ab317ade3ae546dc4e49c698108d58891c373/mathcomp/ssreflect/div.v#L909) and [`Lagrange`](https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/blob/4d5fe7603d53482012734011c70f508e6726959a/mathcomp/fingroup/fingroup.v#L1932)

I think in the long run none of these theorems should carry a proper name (since there is a huge overloading, Gauss, Lagrange, Cauchy, etc theorems are legion), but that there should be an annotation/docstring/attribute to give the common name of the theorem.

Hence, matters little until this is done, and let's keep it as such for now...

discussion.author: jouvelot
discussion.comment:
If these lemmas are considered useful, I could also add to this PR the following ones, which I proved, for completeness, even though I didn't need them:
```
Notation prodn s := (\prod_(i <- s) i).

Lemma prodn_nconsE s n0 n : prodn (ncons n n0 s) = n0 ^ n * prodn s.

Lemma prodn_set_nthE s n0 n m : 
  0 < nth n0 s n ->
  let m' := m * (if size s <= n then nth n0 s n * n0 ^ (n - size s) else 1) in 
  prodn (set_nth n0 s n m) = prodn s * m' %/ (nth n0 s n).
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
Looking around in the codebase, it seems the most common indentation style is something like
```suggestion
Lemma telescope_sumr_eq (a b : nat) (f u : nat -> V) : (a <= b)%N ->
    (forall k, (a <= k < b)%N -> u k = f k.+1 - f k) ->
  \sum_(a <= k < b) u k = f b - f a.
```
Also: please name the nat `n` and `m` as in `telescope_sumr` above.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
Given that `k` and `kab` are not explicitly mentionned and only used on this line you can also use question marks
```suggestion
under eq_big_nat => ? ? do rewrite diffexpr //=.
```
(if you want, the current code is also fine), c.f. https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#naming-of-variables

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
exact: telescope_sumr.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma telescope_prodr_eq (a b : nat) (f u : nat -> R) : (a < b)%N ->
    (forall k, (a < k < b)%N -> f k \is a unit) ->
    (forall k, (a <= k < b)%N -> u k = f k.+1 / f k) ->
  \prod_(a <= k < b) u k = f b / f a.
```

And renames naturals to `n` and `m` as in `telescope_prodr`.

In `telescope_prodr`, the unit ring is not assumed to be commutative, please do the same here.

Last: it may be worth adding a `telescope_prodf_eq` on fields?

review_discussion.author: SnarkBoojum
review_discussion.comment: Indeed `=> ? ?` can be removed, but I find putting the whole proof on a single line a bit too much: it prevents stepping to see what's done.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: I think you missed one.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: I understand, and that would make sense for a complicated proof and/or for educational purpose. Here, inside the core math-comp library, one can safely put everything on a single line without compromising much. In case someone needs to step through it, they can put `.` instead of `;` and that's it.

review_discussion.author: SnarkBoojum
review_discussion.comment:
I do have an educational purpose in mind: these results will be directly used by students when working on exercises, so it really makes sense to make the effort.

Notice that a student will already have a hard time grasping the idea that they can modify something that is given, and will just freak out when after doing so anyway the editor will complain it can't autosave (I just tried with coqide), so I'd rather have a readily readable proof. Newlines are inexpensive and it's worth it.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: We all agree with that in the context of teaching material. The point of Cyril (which I share) is that the code of mathcomp itself is just not that level of teaching material.

review_discussion.author: SnarkBoojum
review_discussion.comment:
Real numbers are used at low level, but their construction is hard -- so if it's not readable at low level, it's not a problem: most students never see a construction anyway.

But these results are to be used at low level and their proofs are low level. That is something budding students do see very early on the blackboard, so it really should be readable in MC.

I can just fold now and patch my code, but then I'm pretty sure that will make three more places where proofs will need to be amended for the liber abaci project...

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
The liber abaci project and mathcomp 1 (and 2 for what matters) are two distinct entities with two different purposes.
- The liber abaci project will certainly need to provide a way to provide both a short version and an extended version of the same proof for the purposes you have in mind. And both proofs will eventually make sense. Indeed, knowing how to write compact proof has an educational purpose albeit different than the one from a beginners perspective
- Now for the sake of homogeneity of the current library, I'd up for the shortest script for trivial theorems (for experts).

Please do not mix the two projects, we can discuss the differences but I'm not sure this is the place.

review_discussion.author: SnarkBoojum
review_discussion.comment: Yes, some discussion will be needed at some point.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: According to WP: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandermonde_matrix the Vandermonde matrix seems to be the transpose, but they also say "Some authors define the Vandermonde matrix as the [transpose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transpose) of the above matrix". I don't know which one we want here?

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> According to WP: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandermonde_matrix the Vandermonde matrix seems to be the transpose, but they also say "Some authors define the Vandermonde matrix as the [transpose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transpose) of the above matrix". I don't know which one we want here?

We do want the transpose of the "normal one" (i.e. the one that is defined here) due to the specific conventions of the mathcomp library wrt that.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: I don't get those specific conventions but I definitely trust you.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
@yoshihiro503 @affeldt-aist also `Vandermonde` must be added to the header of the file (I chose to capitalize and keep the name full because it's a proper name).
PS: is it clear how to proceed to get this PR merged?

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: Thank you @yoshihiro503

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
I suggest the following proof instead.
```suggestion

Definition Vandermonde (R : ringType) (m n : nat) (a : 'rV[R]_n) :=
  \matrix_(i < m, j < n) a 0 j ^+ i.

Lemma det_Vandermonde (R : comRingType) (n : nat) (a : 'rV[R]_n) :
  \det (Vandermonde n a) = \prod_(i < n) \prod_(j < n | i < j) (a 0 j - a 0 i).
Proof.
set V := @Vandermonde R.
elim: n => [|n IHn] in a *; first by rewrite det_mx00 big1// => -[] [].
pose b : 'rV_n := \row_i a 0 (lift 0 i).
pose C : 'M_n := diag_mx (\row_(i < n) (b 0 i - a 0 0)).
pose D : 'M_n.+1 := 1 - a 0 0 *: \matrix_(i, j) (i == j.+1 :> nat)%:R. 
have detD : \det D = 1.
  rewrite det_trig ?big_ord_recl ?mxE ?mulr0 ?subr0 ?eqxx.
    by rewrite ?big1 ?mulr1// => i; rewrite !mxE eqxx ltn_eqF// mulr0 subr0.
  by apply/is_trig_mxP => *; rewrite !mxE ![_ == _]ltn_eqF ?mulr0 ?subr0 ?leqW.
suff: D * V _ _ a = block_mx 1 (const_mx 1) 0 (V _ _ b *m C) :> 'M_(1 + n).
  move=> /(congr1 determinant); rewrite detM detD mul1r => ->.
  rewrite det_ublock det1 mul1r det_mulmx IHn big_ord_recl mulrC; congr (_ * _).
    rewrite big_mkcond big_ord_recl/= mul1r det_diag.
    by under eq_bigr do rewrite !mxE.
  apply: eq_bigr => i _; under eq_bigr do rewrite !mxE.
  by rewrite big_mkcond [RHS]big_mkcond big_ord_recl/= mul1r.
rewrite mulrBl mul1r -scalerAl; apply/matrixP => i j; rewrite !mxE.
under eq_bigr do rewrite !mxE; case: splitP => [{i}_ -> /[!ord1]|{}i ->].
  rewrite !expr0 big1; last by move=> ?; rewrite mul0r.
  by rewrite ?mulr0 ?subr0 ?mxE; case: splitP => k; rewrite ?ord1 mxE//.
under eq_bigr do rewrite eqSS mulr_natl mulrb eq_sym.
rewrite -big_mkcond/= big_ord1_eq exprS ifT// ?leqW// -mulrBl !mxE/=.
case: split_ordP => [{j}_ -> /[!ord1]|{}j ->]; rewrite ?lshift0 ?rshift1 ?mxE.
   by rewrite ?subrr ?mul0r//.
under eq_bigr do rewrite !mxE mulrnAr mulrb.
by rewrite -big_mkcond big_pred1_eq /= mulrC.
Qed.
```
Was there a particular reason why the dimensions were not the same?

discussion.author: thery
discussion.comment:
@CohenCyril  looks good to me. The only thing I am puzzled about is that I am not sure that  `sum_even_poly` and `sum_odd_poly` are "useful" theorems, they seem there only to ease the proof of  `poly_even_odd`.

I've found a direct  proof of `poly_even_odd` without bigop surgery (using induction). Maybe it is better?
```
Lemma poly_even_odd p : even_poly p \Po 'X^2 + (odd_poly p \Po 'X^2) * 'X = p.
Proof.
elim/poly_ind: p => [|n IH nE]; first by rewrite !linear0 mul0r add0r.
rewrite !linearD /= even_polyMX odd_polyMX.
rewrite even_polyC odd_polyC linear0 addr0 comp_polyC.
rewrite -[in RHS]nE addrAC mulrDl [_ * _ + _]addrC -mulrA -expr2.
by rewrite /comp_poly rmorphM hornerM_comm /comm_poly /= map_polyX hornerX.
Qed.
```

discussion.comment: I do prefer the current proof, the intermediate lemmas `sum_even_poly` and `sum_odd_poly` can be of interest (I guess, I haven't used them).

discussion.author: affeldt-aist
discussion.comment:
This PR triggered many renamings. Given the release schedule, the
timing is right but much care seems to be needed to achieve
consensus while avoiding name clashes and too cryptic
identifiers. See for example
https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/wiki/Minutes-October-19-2022.
For the sake of discussion, it is maybe better to be incremental
in this PR, hence this intermediate summary.

Intermediate summary:

Scope of this PR (a priori):
- `_add/D`, `_sub/B`, `_opp/N`, `_mul/M`, `_inv/V`, `_exp/X`
- `dist` out of scope

Renaming so far:
- see the changelog of this PR

Candidates renamings in the queue:
- `lteif_oppl` -> `lteifNl`
- `lteif_oppr` -> `lteifNr`

Not sure:
- `leif_subLR` -> `leifBLR` (too many caps)
- `ltr_paddl`, `ltr_spaddl` -> no change

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment:
> Renaming so far:
> 
>     * see the changelog of this PR
> 
> 
> Candidates renamings in the queue:
> 
>     * `lteif_oppl` -> `lteifNl`
> 
>     * `lteif_oppr` -> `lteifNr`

So, if I understand correctly, this is all going for `l` and `r` suffixes for left and right? While I found them fine after long identifiers, I do prefer one letters like `r` and `n`, for ring and nat, after one letter abbreviations (see `realMr`, `realrM`, `realrMn` for instance).
However there are already a few uses like `mulrDl`, `mulrDr` for distributivity, so I guess it's ok, even if I dislike it.

discussion.author: affeldt-aist
discussion.comment:
> So, if I understand correctly, this is all going for `l` and `r` suffixes for left and right? While I found them fine after long identifiers, I do prefer one letters like `r` and `n`, for ring and nat, after one letter abbreviations (see `realMr`, `realrM`, `realrMn` for instance). However there are already a few uses like `mulrDl`, `mulrDr` for distributivity, so I guess it's ok, even if I dislike it.

I think that everybody felt the same: positional notation should be preferred and `l`, `r` suffixes aren't great.
But in the presence of name clashes, a compromise might be necessary, at least for a while.

discussion.author: erikmd
discussion.comment:
> @pPomCo in order to help reviewing (but again, I can't review myself, being utterly unqualified here), you may want to point to/explain your use case for those new lemmas.

Thanks @proux01 for all your comments!

I believe a bit of history/motivation of a number of lemmas involved in this PR is lacking in the Coq comments, indeed:

All the lemmas related to `fprod` (finite product) were developed by me within this older contribution:

```
@inproceedings{DBLP:conf/types/Martin-DorelS16,
  author    = {{\'{E}}rik Martin{-}Dorel and
               Sergei Soloviev},
  editor    = {Silvia Ghilezan and
               Herman Geuvers and
               Jelena Ivetic},
  title     = {A Formal Study of Boolean Games with Random Formulas as Payoff Functions},
  booktitle = {22nd International Conference on Types for Proofs and Programs, {TYPES}
               2016, May 23-26, 2016, Novi Sad, Serbia},
  series    = {LIPIcs},
  volume    = {97},
  pages     = {14:1--14:22},
  publisher = {Schloss Dagstuhl - Leibniz-Zentrum f{\"{u}}r Informatik},
  year      = {2016},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.4230/LIPIcs.TYPES.2016.14},
  doi       = {10.4230/LIPIcs.TYPES.2016.14},
  timestamp = {Tue, 11 Feb 2020 15:52:14 +0100},
  biburl    = {https://dblp.org/rec/conf/types/Martin-DorelS16.bib},
  bibsource = {dblp computer science bibliography, https://dblp.org}
}
```

in order to formalize the dependent product of finTypes, also endowed with a finType canonical structure.

The main definition is as follows:

```coq
(** Definition and cardinal of [fprod] := dependent product of finTypes *)
Record fprod : predArgType :=
  { fprod_fun : {ffun I -> {i : I & T_ i}} ;
    fprod_prop : [forall i : I, tag (fprod_fun i) == i] }.
```

and it straightforwardly follows (hopefully in a math-comp idiomatic way) the usual pencil-and-paper construction of dependent products in set theory for example, namely:

[![https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian_product#Infinite_Cartesian_products](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/24697ee110c11986a30ca7aa1c8eda0dd5be75f6)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian_product#Infinite_Cartesian_products)

It happened the review of the TYPES-2016-post-proceedings articles was very long (2Y), and at the time we were focusing on submitting a PR for this `fprod` material in math-comp, we noticed Georges' PR https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/294 in April 2019, which thoroughly generalized non-dependent finfuns to dependent finfuns; making our PR idea useless at first sight.

However, when working with @pPomCo on his [formalization of games of incomplete information](https://github.com/pPomCo/coq-belgames-csl2023/), the fact to have this alternative, layered definition of "dependent finfuns" seemed to make several proofs easier, relying on existing math-comp material.

So, one part of this PR #931 directly provides this materiel *(BTW @pPomCo we might want to add a `Co-Authored-By: _` clause in this PR, maybe)*
And the second part amounts to general, albeit seemingly useful material for {finfun.v, finset.v, fintype.v} (so just to recall @proux01: the current use case is just coq-belgames, from file [general_lemmas.v](https://github.com/pPomCo/coq-belgames-csl2023/blob/main/theories/general_lemmas.v))

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
All right, I did a first pass to see more clearly.
I performed many renamings, simplifications and refactorings.
Doing so I introduced
- the predicate `tagged_with` which was left unnamed in your PR.
- the mutual bijections `tag_with` / `untag_with` between `T_ i` and `{x in tagged_with T_ i}`
- the mutual bijections `to_family_tagged_with` / `of_family_tagged_with` between `fprod T_` and `{x in family (tagged_with T_)`

The bijections I introduced suggest two alternative and more concise representations for `fprod` using preexisting ingredients:
- `{x in family (tagged_with T_)}`
- `{dffun forall i : I, {x in tagged_with T_ i}}`
And many of my simplification take advantage of these.

I'm not entirely sure of the purpose of lemma `big_fprod_dep` but it looks like the type of `Q` should be changed (so that the correpondance between `fprod` and other representations is always used in the same direction) but I'm not sure, I must see usecases.

I also left some succint comments questioning the use of some lemmas.

@pPomCo and I will take a look at your refined version and try to address your commented questions.

Can be simplified a bit
```suggestion
Lemma psumr_neq0 (I : eqType) (r : seq I) (P : pred I) (F : I -> R) :
    (forall i, P i -> 0 <= F i) ->
  (\sum_(i <- r | P i) (F i) != 0) = (has (fun i => P i && (0 < F i)) r).
Proof.
move=> F_ge0; rewrite psumr_eq0// -has_predC; apply: eq_has => x /=.
by case Px: (P x); rewrite //= lt_def F_ge0 ?andbT.
Qed.

Lemma psumr_neq0P (I : finType) (P : pred I) (F : I -> R) :
     (forall i, P i -> 0 <= F i) -> \sum_(i | P i) F i <> 0 ->
  (exists i, P i && (0 < F i)).
Proof. by move=> ? /eqP; rewrite psumr_neq0// => /hasP[x _ ?]; exists x. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
If I understand correctly, your goal is to build Monoid structures on min/max to be able to use all bigop lemmas on them. Your solution works well and this is probably the easiest one, hence the best choice for you. You are right that this min/max thing is a clear limitation of the library. However, I'm not sure we want to choose the path you propose here. Indeed, the drawback of defining new functions `omin` and `omax` is that you would have to reprove a bunch of lemmas about them. An alternative would be to declare an order structure on `option` (for instance making `none` greater that everything would make `Order.min` on this structure work as `omin`). Unfortunately this structure is not the same for `omin` and `omax` (`none` should be less than everything in that latter case) and working with different structures on the same type is rather painful. Thus we are pursuing the two following paths in the library:

* generalize lemmas on monoid to semigroups or semigroups with an idempotent element (min and max being both idempotent for every element), this would allow to extend the Monoid hierarchy in the new port to hierarchy builder to use most bigop lemmas on min and max, there is an ongoing PR for that: https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/910
* define an extended type with infinities, like in the `constructive_ereal.v` file in Analysis: https://github.com/math-comp/analysis/blob/master/theories/constructive_ereal.v Thus your `omin` and `omax` would just be `Order.min` and `Order.max` on this type, enabling to reuse all order lemmas. This work still needs to be integrated in MathComp proper.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Nitpicking, but the conventions are `n` and `m`
```suggestion
Notation "n = m :> 'int'"  := (@eq int n%Z m%Z) (only parsing)  : ring_scope.
Notation "n = m :> 'int'"  := (Posz n = Posz m) (only printing)  : ring_scope.
Notation "n == m :> 'int'" := ((n%Z : int) == (m%Z : int)) (only parsing)
  : ring_scope.
Notation "n == m :> 'int'" := (Posz n == Posz m) (only printing) : ring_scope.
Notation "n != m :> 'int'" := ((n%Z : int) != (m%Z : int)) (only parsing)
  : ring_scope.
Notation "n != m :> 'int'" := (Posz n != Posz m) (only printing) : ring_scope.
Notation "n <> m :> 'int'" := (not (@eq int n%Z m%Z)) (only parsing)
  : ring_scope.
```

commits.author: proux01
commits.message:
Add parsing notations for _ = _ :> int and the like

This way `2 = 1 :> int` is parsed as `2%Z = 1%Z` and not `2%R = 1%R`
(that is `Posz 2 = Posz 1` (matching the already existing printing only
rule for `_ = _ :> int`) and not `intmul GRIng.one 2 = GRing.one`).
This should enable to retrieve the parsing behavior of `_ = _ :> int`
before the introduction of the number notation in ring_scope.

commits.author: proux01
commits.message:
Generalize lemmas from monoid to semigroups

Many lemmas on monoids (particularly abelian ones) where already valid
on (abelian) semigroups. This generalization could be improved by
adding semigroups to the monoid hierarchy, when porting to HB.

Some lemmas don't require a monoid with a neutral element but only an
idempotent element. This is particularly useful for min/max that are
idempotent but generally don't have a neutral element.

@thery what do you think?

review_discussion.author: erikmd
review_discussion.comment:
To give more insight, `RUN` admits two syntaxes:

* the **shell form**:  
  `RUN cmd1 && cmd2`  
  (which uses `/bin/sh -c` as implicit shell, or `/bin/bash --login  -c` thanks to the previous `SHELL` command)

* the **exec form**:  
  `RUN ["prog", "arg1", ""]`  
  which is more "precise" because we can specify the shell in an explicit way, but is very rarely used in practice because it's heavier.

So this patch is just a convenience refactoring that amounts to removing one level of brackets/quoting.

Regarding # hadolint ignore, it's just a Dockerfile linter annotation I had added when preparing the Dockerfiles for stable versions of math-comp.

I've just run it again (`docker run --rm -i hadolint/hadolint < Dockerfile`) and it spotted more details; will force-push another commit.

discussion.author: eupp
discussion.comment:
> Thanks @eupp ! I've made a few additional simplifications / whitespace cleaning. If you agree and there is no more comment, I'll merge by the end of (next) week.

@proux01 thank you for cleaning up my proofs!
I have few remarks:

1) If we keep the name `nth_seq1`, should we also rename `nth_nil` to `nth_seq0`?

2) In `count_set_nth_small` is the suffix `_small` is standard naming convention in `ssreflect`?
I can see only one lemma in `seq.v` following this convention: `perm_small_eq`.
At the same time many other similar lemmas use alternative convention with suffix `_leq` (e.g. `has_take_leq`, `in_take_leq`, etc). I personally prefer the latter (with `_leq`), but it's up to maintainers to decide :)

3) I was wondering, should we add more lemmas about `set_nth` that can be deduced from `count_set_nthE`? 
For example, lemmas about `has`, `all`, etc? I didn't need them in my project (from which I ported current lemmas), but they also can be useful. Perhaps we should add them in a follow-up PR?

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment:
1. No, `_nil` seems to be the usual suffix for `[::]` (`Search "_nil" in seq.` returns results whereas `seq0` doesn't exist) whereas the suffix for lists of length one seems to be `_seq1`.

2. Right, let's go for `_ltn`.

3. I'd say the rules are
   * when adding a lemma, add all lemmas of the same "family" (that's why I complemented `count_set_nthF` with `count_set_nth_ltn`)
   * don't clutter things with lemmas that are too direct combinations of existing lemmas

   So yes a further PR may be worth it.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
I would expect a more generic lemma, like
```suggestion
Lemma set_nthE :
  set_nth x0 s n x
  = if n < size s then take n s ++ x :: drop n.+1 s
    else s ++ ncons (n - size s) x0 [:: x].
```
from which the current lemma can be derived.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Same, there should be a more generic lemma from which this could be derived.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
I would suggest stating this using `reflect` since its converse also holds:
```suggestion
Lemma mkseq_uniqP (f : nat -> T) n :
  reflect {in iota 0 n &, injective f} (uniq (mkseq f n)).
Proof.
apply: (iffP idP); last by move/map_inj_in_uniq ->; apply: iota_uniq.
move=> /(uniqP (f 0)) Huniq i j; rewrite !mem_iota add0n !leq0n /= => Hi Hj fij.
by apply: Huniq; rewrite ?size_mkseq // !nth_mkseq.
Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: ggonthier
review_discussion.comment:
It would be better to use `gtn n` rather that `iota 0 n` as the injectivity domain, since this would avoid exposing users to the internals of `mkseq`. Perhaps
```suggestion
  reflect {in gtn n &, injective f} (uniq (mkseq f n)).
Proof.
apply: (equivP (uniqP (f 0))); rewrite size_mkseq.
by split=> injf i j lti ltj; have:= injf i j lti ltj; rewrite !nth_mkseq.
```

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment:
LGTM, but

- It feels that users will rarely use these, because it takes too much remembering that these pattern exist.
- This suggests that the "RHS" notation should be usable to denote the right-hand side of equalities and inequalities alike.  How would that be possible?  It seems that one would need to be able to define "multi-patterns" (disjunctions of patterns), in the same way that we already define multi-rules.  On the surface, it seems an easy thing to define, but digging more deeply, it feels that providing this together with extensibility (as in extending multi-rules) is quite hard actually.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: Another issue I have with this PR is that it corrects some spacing problems which are independent from the subject in the title.  It is too bad that these corrections will be forgotten if this PR is not incorporated.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> * This suggests that the "RHS" notation should be usable to denote the right-hand side of equalities and inequalities alike.  How would that be possible?

I tried at some point and failed: this was too ambiguous, e.g. for which `r` would `RHS` match `y` in `r x y`? 
Even if we narrow `r` down to a few symbols (e.g. through some for of table, e.g. canonical projections),
many goals containing `_ <= _` also contain `_ = _`, if we are not more precise than just `RHS` how do we specify?
The ad-hoc solution here is to tailor customized patterns for the most frequently used...

Like many things in ssr most people will not use it until they really feel the need, and that's when they must be able find them through documentation. Maybe we should rewrite a mathcomp local addentum to https://coq.inria.fr/refman/proof-engine/ssreflect-proof-language.html for that purpose?

discussion.author: affeldt-aist
discussion.comment:
The topic was discussed during the last mathcomp-dev meeting, see https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/wiki/Minutes-April-06-2022.
After the meeting @gares figured out a way based on @CohenCyril 's idea:
```
Notation LEFT symb := (X in symb X _)%pattern.
```
with the following comment: "one still needs to put in %pattern scope some notations for the usual infix symbols."

Should it come as a replacement or an addition?

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> Should it come as a replacement or an addition?

I would vote for "as an addition"

discussion.author: gares
discussion.comment: I guess one needs to make the scope explicit around symb as well. And test it a little, since I did not do it very carefully.

discussion.author: thery
discussion.comment: a pity we can't write  `[LEFT <=]` and `[LEFT =]`

discussion.author: gares
discussion.comment: I think you can if you add these notations in the pattern scope (not as infix, just as atoms).

discussion.author: thery
discussion.comment:
I am pretty bad at notation I tried to add
`Notation "LEFT <=" := (X in X <= _)%pattern (at level 10).`
and it broke everything :see_no_evil:

discussion.author: gares
discussion.comment:
I'm not on my pc
```
Notation "<=" := leq : symb_scope.
Notation "LEFT f" := (X in f%symb X _)%pattern.
```

discussion.author: affeldt-aist
discussion.comment:
> I would vote for "as an addition"

Then we can maybe merge this one for now and issue for the more general pattern (it might require some testing).

discussion.author: thery
discussion.comment:
I have tried
```coq
Notation "<=" := leq : symb_scope.
Delimit Scope symb_scope with symb.
Notation "'LEFT' f" := (X in f%symb X _)%pattern (at level 10).
Goal 1 <= 2 .
```
and I get a
`Unknown interpretation for notation "<=".`
for the `<=` in the goal.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: I think we need to create a new nonterminal (a.k.a. custom entry) for that otherwise we will screw up the main parser.

discussion.author: thery
discussion.comment:
ok this works
```coq
Declare Custom Entry symb.
Notation "<=" := leq (in custom symb at level 0).
Notation "'LEFT' f" := (X in f X _)%pattern (f in custom symb, at level 10).
Goal 1 <= 2 .
rewrite -[LEFT <=](addn1).
```

review_discussion.author: thery

review_discussion.author: affeldt-aist

review_discussion.author: thery
review_discussion.comment: my poor brain prefers consistency :wink:

review_discussion.author: thery

review_discussion.author: affeldt-aist
review_discussion.comment: The last push force added leqLHS, etc. They seem quite useful. As for adding eqLHS as a synonymous of LHS, it looks like it better be an addition to Coq's ssrmatching.v. Should we PR this to Coq?

discussion.author: ggonthier
discussion.comment:
As it stands, part of the change  is not backward compatible : adding the new `[in A]` notation obviously is, but using it in the `[predU A & B]`, `[predI A & B]`, etc. notation is not. It breaks various fragile scripts that rely on `rewrite inE` of such notation exposing a `mem A x` (really `pred_of_simpl (simpl_of_mem (mem A)) x`) subterm, as explained the rationale.
   The PR fixes this in `mathcomp` proper, as do math-comp/odd-order#40 and coq-community/fourcolor#42 for `odd-order` and `foucolor`, respectively (in a backward compatible way), but CI also indicates a similar failure in `graph-theory`, for which I've yet to propose a fix (I'm not set up to compile it right now).
   It thus seems prudent to fix the clients before pushing the full PR to `coq/ssrbool`, though of course the definition of `[in A]` could be pushed immediately.

commits.author: ggonthier
commits.message:
Add [in A] notation.

Add `[in A]` notation for `fun x => x \in A`, the natural applicative equivalent of a collective predicate `A`.
Replace `(mem A)` and `[mem A]`, which had a similar purpose but require an explicit `/=` or `inE` to turn `mem A x` to `x \in A`, which is sometimes awkward.
Remove the Coq 8.10 compatibility code from `ssrbool.v`, which is actually incompatible with Coq < 8.13.
Add lemmas for `all` and `map`: `allT`, `all_mapT`, `inj_in_map`, `mapK_in`.

commits.author: proux01

Remove coercion Leaf_of_nat in ssrAC

When removing the uniform inheritance condition for coercions in Coq,

broke ssrAC.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
* Nothing depends on ssralg here, so this could be put at the end of bigop.v.
* When adding definitions, like `shrink` and `empty`, they should be documented. But since they are used in only one lemma, maybe we just don't need specific definitions.
* it seems the `shrink` hypothesis can be simplified to ` k, n < k < m  op (f n k) (f k k.+1) = f n k.+1` which leads to the following simplified proof
```suggestion
Lemma telescope_op R (idx : R) (op : Monoid.law idx) f n m :
  n <= m -> (n = m -> f n n = idx) ->
  (forall k, n < k < m -> op (f n k) (f k k.+1) = f n k.+1) ->
  \big[op/idx]_(n <= i < m) f i i.+1 = f n m.
Proof.
have [ltnm _ _ | // | <- _ ->//] := ltngtP; last by rewrite big_geq.
elim: m ltnm => [//| m IHm]; rewrite ltnS.
have [ltnm _ s | // | <- _ _] := ltngtP; last by rewrite big_nat1.
have snm : forall q, n < q < m -> op (f n q) (f q q.+1) = f n q.+1.
  by move=> q /andP[nq /leqW qm]; apply/s/andP.
by rewrite big_nat_recr 1?ltnW// IHm// s// ltnm/=.
Qed.
Arguments telescope_op [R idx op] f [n m].
```
(there might be a way to get rid of the Monoid hypothesis, but I didn't manage that)

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
This should also be in bigop.
It' also seems inverted to me.
```suggestion
Lemma telescope_sumn n m f :
  n <= m -> {in [pred i | n <= i <= m] &, {homo f : x y / x <= y}} ->
  \sum_(n <= k < m) (f k.+1 - f k) = f m - f n.
Proof.
move=> lenm homof; set f' := fun i j => f j - f i.
rewrite -/(f' n m); under eq_bigr => k _ do rewrite -/(f' k k.+1).
apply: telescope_op; rewrite /f' ?subnn//= => k /andP[ltnk ltkm].
rewrite addnBAC ?subnKC//; apply: homof;
  rewrite ?inE ?(ltnW ltnk) ?(ltnW ltkm)//.
- by rewrite (leqW (ltnW ltnk)).
- by rewrite leqnn (ltnW (ltn_trans ltnk ltkm)).
Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
The new proof should be shorter
```suggestion
move=> lenm; apply: (telescope_op (fun i j => f j - f i) lenm (fun=> subrr _)).
by move=> k _ /=; rewrite addrCA addrAC subrr add0r.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
New proof should be shorter
```suggestion
move=> allu ltnm; rewrite (telescope_op (fun i j => f i / f j) (ltnW ltnm))//.
  by move=> /eqP; rewrite ltn_eqF.
move=> k nkm; rewrite /= mulrA divrK//; exact: allu.
```

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment:
Thanks for taking the time looking at this PR and all the suggestions :) 

> * Nothing depends on ssralg here, so this could be put at the end of bigop.v.

I agree that the code should be dispatched somewhere else. I put it in one place, where its application was more meaningful, to make looking at it easier at the start of the review process. Should have I done the dispatch right from the start?

> * When adding definitions, like `shrink` and `empty`, they should be documented. But since they are used in only one lemma, maybe we just don't need specific definitions.

It seems to me that `shrink` could, if deemed sufficiently useful, actually be put in nat.v. (with a better name). This is a simplification I had to do in a project, on nats and also on ints.

> it seems the `shrink` hypothesis can be simplified to ` k, n < k < m  op (f n k) (f k k.+1) = f n k.+1` which leads to the following simplified proof

This is what I used at the start, but 1) this equality condition is only needed on a subset of the domain of `f`, which thus makes the subsequent lemmas stronger, and 2) it turned out to be needed, or at least useful, for the variant of the telescope I needed, which operated on ordinals. 

> (there might be a way to get rid of the Monoid hypothesis, but I didn't manage that)

I thought the Monoid was necessary for the `\big` construct.

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment:
> This should also be in bigop. 

I agree.

> It' also seems inverted to me.

I followed the pattern already used in ssralg.v, so that I didn't have to change one single line of the file there, just introduce the `telescope_op` abstraction.

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment: Should I dispatch the various proof elements in the files we discussed? Any suggestion about where exactly?

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
> I agree that the code should be dispatched somewhere else. I put it in one place, where its application was more meaningful, to make looking at it easier at the start of the review process. Should have I done the dispatch right from the start?

As you prefer, that's not needed for a first version of the pull request, just to discuss the change.
But that would have to be done at some point before merging.

> It seems to me that `shrink` could, if deemed sufficiently useful, actually be put in nat.v. (with a better name). This is a simplification I had to do in a project, on nats and also on ints.

Maybe. I currently think that just the `telescope_op` lemma doesn't expose such a need. But if you have other uses that would justify that, feel free to share them.

> This is what I used at the start, but 1) this equality condition is only needed on a subset of the domain of `f`, which thus makes the subsequent lemmas stronger, and 2) it turned out to be needed, or at least useful, for the variant of the telescope I needed, which operated on ordinals.

Then maybe add this lemma to the PR. Currently, it feels like proving a lemma under an hypothesis that is more complicated and stronger than needed, which is a shame.

BTW, I wonder whether the hypothesis about `n` and `m` in `telescope_op` shouldn't be `n < m` rather than `n <= m`, that would remove the need for the `n = m -> f n n = idx` hypothesis, and the equality case can easily be proved when needed (it doesn't depend on `telescope_op` itself).

> I thought the Monoid was necessary for the `\big` construct.

No (although it is very common), see `big_nat_recl` for instance (compared to `big_nat_recr`).

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
> Should I dispatch the various proof elements in the files we discussed? Any suggestion about where exactly?

I would say at the end of `bigop.v`, there for instance https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/blob/master/mathcomp/ssreflect/bigop.v#L2056

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: I mean, `telescope_sumr` is in the order `\sum_(n  k < m) (f k.+1 - f k) = f m - f n`, as well as `telescope_prodf`. Only `telescope_prodr` is in the order `\prod_(n  k < m) (f k / f k.+1) = f n / f m`, but it holds a comment `(* Due to noncommutativity, fractions are inverted. *)`. So the order you suggested looks to me like "inverted" as per the existing code.

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment: Oh, I see what you mean. I'm pushing a new version.

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment:
- I'll try to clean up the lemma on ordinals I have to see whether that would more motivate the constraint in `shrink`. BTW, it seems to me that this added constraint in `shrink` makes `telescope_op` stronger, since the equality property only needs to be true on a subdomain of `shrink`.
- For `n <= m`or `n < m`, I don't know what's best. The lemma is more general with the inequality, and avoids users to prove the `=` case at the price of the `empty` definition. Both cases are present in `ssralg.v`. 
- I'll keep the functions in one location for now, and will move them in `bigop.v` once the code is finalized, then. Thanks for the suggestion.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
> For n <= mor n < m, I don't know what's best.

I think we need both: `telescope_op : n < m -> ...` and `telescope_op_leq : n <= m -> (n = m -> f n n = idx) -> ...`

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma telescope_sumn n m f : 
```
to be consistent with the other names in ssralg.v

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment:
> > For n <= mor n < m, I don't know what's best.
> 
> I think we need both: `telescope_op : n < m -> ...` and `telescope_op_leq : n <= m -> (n = m -> f n n = idx) -> ...`

Ok, let's try that. I'm pushing these two versions.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
BTW, do we agree that
```forall k, n < k < m -> op (f n k) (f k k.+1) = f n k.+1```
is a weaker hypothesis than
```forall p q r, p < q < r -> (n <= p /\ r <= m) -> op (f p q) (f q r) = f p r```
(just taking p := n, q := k and r := k+1) thus making the lemma in my suggested change above stronger?

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment:
Oh, sorry, I misread your previous question, and thought you were only getting rid of the `(n <= p /\ r <= m)` condition, which I needed for the ordinal-based lemma I had in a project:
```
Variable (k :nat) (f : 'I_k.+1 -> nat ) (af : {homo f : x y /~ x <= y}).

Definition ord_pred m (j : 'I_m) : 'I_m. 
have j1: j.-1 < m by rewrite (leq_ltn_trans _ (ltn_ord j)) // leq_pred.
exact: Ordinal j1.
Defined.

Lemma sum_diffs (l h : 'I_k.+1) : 
  l < h -> \sum_(s < k.+1 | l < s <= h) (f (ord_pred s) - f s) = f l - f h.
```
for which the bound condition was needed (and where my hunt for a more general solution started). So, yes, indeed, your suggestion is a weaker hypothesis, and probably enough; I'll reuse your shorter proof, and see whether I can make all my use cases work with this.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
You can make `f` explicit
```suggestion
Arguments telescope_op [R idx op] f [n m].
Arguments telescope_op_leq [R idx op] f [n m].
```
to avoid the `@telescope_op _ _ _` below.

review_discussion.author: jouvelot
review_discussion.comment:
All the use cases mentioned in the motivation header of this PR can be nicely adapted to the current definitions, except for `sum_diffs`, which deals with ordinals. For this, I had to introduce a (stronger) version of `telescope_sumn`, as follows:
```
Lemma telescope_sumn' n m f : 
  n <= m -> {in [pred i | n <= i <= m] &, {homo f : x y / x <= y}} ->
  \sum_(n <= k < m) (f k.+1 - f k) = f m - f n.
```
Maybe it's possible to avoid the (meaningful, btw) restriction on the `homo` constraint, but I'm not sure. Since this provable using `telescope_op_leq`, maybe it's not worth mentioning it.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Indeed, we can add this.


discussion.author: jouvelot
discussion.comment:
For quantifier completeness, maybe we could add the related lemma:
```
Lemma not_exists_eqP f1 f2 : reflect (~ (exists x, f1 x = f2 x)) (~~ [exists x, f1 x == f2 x]).
```
although I'm not sure there is a use case for it.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: In MathComp, we try when adding a lemma to also add lemmas of the same "family", so that would make sense, even if we don't see a use case (yet).

discussion.author: ggonthier
discussion.comment:
I'm a little curious about the use case for such lemmas. In principle, they should not be needed, as contrapositives for `reflect` are intended to be covered by the `introN` and `elimN` view hints, i.e., `move/eqfunP` should work the same as `move/not_eqfunP`, unless there's a double negation, as in `~ ~ (f1 =1 f2) -> ...` (was that the issue?). Direct application,
as in `not_eqfunP (neq_fg : ~~ [forall x, f x == g x])` will also work, but the `elimN` hint must be given explicitly (as in `elimN eqfunP neq_fg`), since the default (coercion) is ` elimT`.

discussion.author: jouvelot
discussion.comment: Oh, great! I didn't know that reflection would also work "past" the negation operator. In this case, my PR can be discarded, unless we want to keep it for the double negation case, as mentioned by Georges.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: Thanks!

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma not_eqfunP f1 f2 : reflect (~ (forall x, f1 x = f2 x)) (~~ [forall x, f1 x == f2 x]).
Proof.
apply/(iffP idP); first by apply: contraNnot => /eqfunP.
by apply: contra_notN => /eqfunP.
Qed.
```

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: @jouvelot I don't think we have that currently in MathComp, so feel free to pen a separate PR.

discussion.author: jouvelot
discussion.comment:
Hi Pierre (@proux01 ), 
I wrote a specification and proof for the following BubbleSort-like lemma:
```
bs_spec
     : forall s : seq nat,
       uniq s ->
       exists ts : seq transposition,
         let '(all_bubbles, s') := swap aperm s ts in 
         all_bubbles /\ up_sorted s'
```
which fulfills what I was looking for. Since it's a big complicated, I'm not sure this would be acceptable for a mathcomp PR. Would you please be willing to have a quick look at the file `bubblesort.v` in the public repo [https://github.com/jouvelot/mech.v](https://github.com/jouvelot/mech.v) to give me some advice about this?
Thanks.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: Hi @jouvelot , sorry for the late answer. I finally got a look. IINM you want to prove that every permutation of a finite set is the composition of finitely many transpositions. I don't know that part of MathComp very well but it seems to me that this result is already proved as `prod_tpermP` in `perm.v`. Why don't you use that?

discussion.author: jouvelot
discussion.comment: No problem, @proux01. One limitation of `prod_termP` I see comes from the fact that the permutations in `perm.v` for a sequence `s` deal with the values in `s`, while I need to deal with both the values and their indices. The theorem I suggest sees transpositions as pairs of indices. The motivation for this is that one can then limit oneself, to sort upward `s`, to applying transpositions that all have the property of being non-sorted bubbles (i.e., if `i1 < i2`, then `nth s i2 < nth s i1`), which is what bubble sort uses. In addition of providing a specification for a kind of bubble sort algorithm, this theorem is a key ingredient to prove some lemmas in `mech.v`, which is a framework under development to specify auction mechanisms (in the Mechanism Design sense).

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment:
Interesting. I wonder whether you could only go with indices (as values can be retrieved with `nth`). If it were me, I would probably have a detailed look at the proof of `prod_tpermP` and see if I can mimick it for my (stronger) property.
Anyway, to answer the initial question, "duplicating" the definition of transposition and redoing on nat things that were (for a small part) already there on ordinals seems a bit wasteful and I wouldn't consider this ready for a pull request (at least in its current state).

discussion.author: jouvelot
discussion.comment:
I agree with your assessment. 

- I thought using `nat` instead of ordinals would be more useful, since it would have more impact than limiting it to finite types (which is ironic, since I use mostly ordinals and tuples in `mech.v`; in fact, I had to add a layer to map the `nat`-based version of my lemma to ordinals, so that I could use it in `mech.v`). 
- I also thought about using "mathcomp indices" instead of explicit ones, but they can sometimes be a bit difficult to use when duplicates exist in sequences (I use it nonetheless in the proof, since this issue is not a factor there). 
- The duplications you mention are indeed unfortunate, although most of the `max`-based lemmas are not present in `bigop.v` (and may not be applicable to `nat`, anyhow, if they were there). Some of them could in fact be added to `bigop.v`, if deemed useful.
- For now, I'll have, as you suggest, a detailed look at `prod_termP`. 

I managed to get my "bubble lemma" to work as expected in my project. In my mind, the question remains of whether getting a nicer-looking version of it would be of value to the mathcomp community, or whether I should limit myself to a finite-type-only version ... or just drop it.

Thanks a lot for your advice.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma up_log_eq p n k : 1 < p -> p ^ n < k <= p ^ n.+1 -> up_log p k = n.+1.
Proof.
move=> p_gt1 /andP[npLk kLpn]; apply/anti_leq.
rewrite up_log_min //= -(ltn_exp2l _ _ p_gt1).
by apply: leq_trans npLk (up_logP _ _).
ed.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma up_logMp p n : 1 < p -> 0 < n -> up_log p (p * n) = (up_log p n).+1.
Proof.
case: p => [//|p] p_gt0.
case: n => [//|[|n]] _; first by rewrite muln1 up_lognn// up_log1.
apply: up_log_eq => //.
rewrite expnS leq_pmul2l// up_logP// andbT.
rewrite -[up_log _ _]prednK ?up_log_gt0 ?p_gt0 //.
by rewrite expnS ltn_pmul2l// up_log_gtn.
Qed.
```

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment:
This generalization certainly makes sense. In fact, coq-communnity/reglang uses an eqType version of `bigmax_sup`:
```
Lemma bigmax_seq_sup (T : eqType) (s:seq T) (P : pred T) F k m :
  k \in s -> P k -> m <= F k -> m <= \max_(i <- s | P i) F i.
Proof. move => A B C. by rewrite (big_rem k) //= B leq_max C. Qed.
```
So maybe it's a good idea do generalize that as well.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril

Here follows the lemma with the "correct" generality, which should bear the name `leq_bigmax`
```suggestion
Lemma leq_bigmax (I : Type) r (P : {pred I}) F i0 :
  P i0 -> F i0 <= \max_(i <- r | P i) F i.
```
Now, if you also want the specialization to an `eqType` and the `i0 \in r`, you can name it `leq_bigmax_seq`.

discussion.author: hivert
discussion.comment: May I suggest to take the opportunity to add all the easy lemmas about complex conjugation such as `1^* = 1` or `(x + y)^* = x^* + y^*`. Admitedly, they are all one liner thank to the various `rmorph?`. However, they are easier to apply if you have exactly the right lemma. For example, I'd rather do `rewrite -conjC1`, instead of `rewrite -(rmorph1 [rmorphism of (fun x => x^*)]) /=.`

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> May I suggest to take the opportunity to add all the easy lemmas about complex conjugation such as `1^* = 1` or `(x + y)^* = x^* + y^*`. Admitedly, they are all one liner thank to the various `rmorph?`. However, they are easier to apply if you have exactly the right lemma. For example, I'd rather do `rewrite -conjC1`, instead of `rewrite -(rmorph1 [rmorphism of (fun x => x^*)]) /=.`

`conjC0` and `conjC1` were already there, I added `conjCN1` and I will not add the `conjCD`, etc, since the pattern of the RHS is sufficient to infer the morphism, so the contrived form  `rewrite -(rmorphD [rmorphism of (fun x => x^*)]) /=.` would ne be necessary anyway. I think this is a good compromise and will stop there.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
This file should be removed when using the same version as the toolbox. Otherwise one can run
```shell
% nix-shell --run "updateNixpkgsMaster"
```
or to update to the current nixpkgs master
```shell
% nix-shell --run "updateNixpkgs owner branch"
```
to update to a custom branch.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Caching is done via https://www.cachix.org/ and there is a token in the math-comp organization to authenticate and store the results. Any CI build is stored globally and can be used on one's own computer by running
```shell
nix-env -iA nixpkgs.cachix
cachix use coq
cachix use coq-community
cachix use math-comp
```
as described in https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/wiki/Using-nix

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
There is a lot of information here: https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/wiki/Using-nix
please tell me if anything is missing.

commits.message:
[CI] Attempt to document Nix CI

Co-authored-by: Cyril COhen <cohen@crans.org>

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: The nixppkgs PR NixOS/nixpkgs#142174 just got merged, so we may rather want to wait a few days and update nixpkgs here.

discussion.author: proux01
discussion.comment: And multinomials 8.12 is ok by applying @erikmd suggestion from https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/793#issuecomment-946141996

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: @proux01 I am going to remove the draft status and merge this if you agree?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
@proux01 thanks for patching this. I still do not understand why it is broken though...
CC: @erikmd @Zimmi48

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Me neither, and particularly why it only breaks for 8.12?

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment:
How can Ireproduce / see the error log?

OCaml is not a propagated build input of Coq so you need to explicitly depend on it to rely on native compilation, but in the case of a Dune build, it is automatically included in the build inputs so this doesn't seem to be a valid explanation.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
> How can Ireproduce / see the error log?

By removing the above `preBuild` for instance. Here is a failing job https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/793/checks?check_run_id=3905504301

The explanation about OCaml indeed seems promising (although still wondering why only for 8.12).

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment: OK, thanks for the link. I think this kind of error just means that Coq is improperly installed from the point of view of ocamlfind. There could be a bug with the Nix packaging of Coq 8.12.

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment: To confirm this, one would need to run `nix-shell` for this and run `ocamlfind -query coq.kernel`. That being said, I just did that with the current nixpkgs master and `nix-shell -I nixpkgs=. -p coq_8_12 coq_8_12.findlib` and it worked fine.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Same here with the nixpkgs version used by mathcomp.

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment: So I just ran `nix-shell --argstr job multinomials` with the code from this PR and what I got was that OCaml is there but `ocamlfind` is not. This might explain the error.

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment: So indeed, we only add `ocaml` to the build inputs when using Dune, but not `findlib`. So `findlib` must be explicitly added to the `extraBuildInputs` if native compilation is to be used.

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment: @CohenCyril That's a bit annoying that to test a patch that only does a modification to the multinomials overlay, I have to recompile all of mathcomp, because Nix considers the source to have changed.

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment:
Anyway, this patch seems to work:

```diff
diff --git a/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix b/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix
index cb238da..cb2d884 100644
--- a/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix
+++ b/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix
@@ -36,10 +36,7 @@ with lib; mkCoqDerivation {
     patchShebangs configure || true
   '';
 
-  preBuild = ''
-    # dune + native compilation + Nix seems currently broken, so disactivate it
-    cp -f src/dune.in src/dune
-  '';
+  extraBuildInputs = [ coq.ocamlPackages.findlib ];
 
   propagatedBuildInputs =
     [ mathcomp.ssreflect mathcomp.algebra mathcomp-finmap mathcomp-bigenough ];
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
Thanks! We don't want to do native compilation however, so we should probably keep the previous patch.
And I now understand why it only broke for 8.12, that's just what @erikmd wrote in multinomial's configure script: https://github.com/math-comp/multinomials/blob/master/configure#L34

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment:
Actually, I was testing with the wrong version (8.13). When testing with Coq 8.12, I get a different failure but I think it means that the dependencies were built without native-compute:

```
File "./src/./NSsrMultinomials_freeg.native", line 18, characters 3-61:
18 |   (Nmathcomp_ssreflect_seq.const_Nmathcomp_ssreflect_seq_uniq
        ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Error: Unbound module Nmathcomp_ssreflect_seq
Error: Native compiler exited with status 2

        coqc src/.xfinmap.aux,src/NSsrMultinomials_xfinmap.{cmi,cmxs},src/xfinmap.{glob,vo} (exit 1)
(cd _build/default && /nix/store/rais5zqvn73xn2w99jrfz30ysakgdc7n-coq-8.12.2/bin/coqc -w -ambiguous-paths -w -notation-overridden -w -redundant-canonical-projection -w -projection-no-head-constant -w -deprecated-native-compiler-option -native-output-dir . -native-compiler on -nI /nix/store/rais5zqvn73xn2w99jrfz30ysakgdc7n-coq-8.12.2/lib/ocaml/4.10.2/site-lib/coq/kernel -nI src -R src SsrMultinomials src/xfinmap.v)
File "./src/./NSsrMultinomials_xfinmap.native", line 14, characters 14-108:
14 |   (Obj.magic (Nmathcomp_bigenough_bigenough.Construct_Nmathcomp_bigenough_bigenough_BigEnough_big_rel_of_0_1((
                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Error: Unbound module Nmathcomp_bigenough_bigenough
Error: Native compiler exited with status 2
```

So my best guess on why it doesn't fail with Coq 8.13 is just that the native-compiler is not run at all with Coq 8.13.

EDIT: confirmed in the comment above.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
> I think it means that the dependencies were built without native-compute:

yes

> So my best guess on why it doesn't fail with Coq 8.13 is just that the native-compiler is not run at all with Coq 8.13.

Exactly, Erik's script in multinomials basically activates native compilation only for Coq 8.12 (c.f. my link above).

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Let's merge this for now, and then I'd like to discuss what should land in nixpkgs.
Shouldn't coq propagate the buildInput findlib?

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
> Shouldn't coq propagate the buildInput findlib?

I don't know, the way native compilation works in the OPAM world is through a `coq-native` metapackage. There is currently no equivalent on the Nix side, so nothing would build with native compilation anyway, which makes the addition of findlib rather useless in practice.

review_discussion.author: Zimmi48
review_discussion.comment: If we follow the split world approach, we could have `coqPackages_withnative` where OCaml and findlib are available (recall that OCaml is not available by default for packages who do not build with Dune) and the right configure options are passed.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: If that's easy to do, that would be nice (we have no user yet, but testing some packages in CI with native compilation would definitely make sense).

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
> If we follow the split world approach, we could have `coqPackages_withnative` where OCaml and findlib are available (recall that OCaml is not available by default for packages who do not build with Dune) and the right configure options are passed.

I would imagine a coqPackages.withnative which could thus be overloaded.

> @pi8027 could you test if this is enough to solve the inefficiencies encountered in apery?

Indeed. I will report ASAP.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
math-comp/apery#4 compiles without almost any issue! I have just changed one line which was already a bottleneck with MathComp 1.12.

With this PR:
```
make  595.03s user 9.88s system 99% cpu 10:05.20 total
```
With MathComp 1.12:
```
make  741.40s user 9.96s system 99% cpu 12:31.72 total
```

Interestingly, it is now faster than MathComp 1.12, although the result without native compilation could be different...

https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/793/checks?check_run_id=3905504301#step:12:22

discussion.author: erikmd
discussion.comment:
> Ah nevermind there is also a failure on the nix side, just for coq 8.12, which I do not understand... https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/793/checks?check_run_id=3905504301#step:12:22

Hi @CohenCyril, I've just have a look and I don't know either what's the meaning of
```
Error: Library "coq.kernel" not found.
```
as this seems to be a dune-related error

But I see that two lines above this error, there is:
```
coq-native support enabled!
```
while I believe (IINM) that in the Nix packaging of multinomials, native compilation was expected to be off.

So if the error and this flag were related, I believe I have a simple solution that wouldn't require a change in multinomials codebase, just in the Nix packaging of `coq-mathcomp-multinomials.{dev & upcoming releases 1.5.5+}`:

actually, the only purpose of the 50-line configure script I had proposed in multinomials is [this if-then-else](https://github.com/math-comp/multinomials/blob/348222aeee8ce02f84fc1ceaf1ff4f286cd29db1/configure#L39-L44):
```
    if coq_native_compiler; then
        echo 'coq-native support enabled!' >&2
        sed -e 's/;coq-native-disabled; \?//' "$dir/src/dune.in" > "$dir/src/dune"
    else
        cat "$dir/src/dune.in" > "$dir/src/dune"
    fi
```
Admittedly, the coq_native_compiler condition is more strict for Coq 8.12.1 (the minimal version of Coq that is compatible with the `(mode native)` of dune  2.8), because of several reasons (briefly speaking, the 'COQ_NATIVE_COMPILER_DEFAULT=yes' string that can output `coqc -config` cannot be found in Coq <8.13, and we cannot do some opam query to see if the "coq-native" package has been installed, precisely given this detection/guess has to be done by the build system layer, agnostic w.r.t. the chosen package manager).

But, if you confirm that the Nix packaging need not enabling the `-native-compiler yes` option, a simple solution could be to replace the `./configure` Nix build step with just `cp -f src/dune.in src/dune`

I'm not Nix-savvy at all, but hopefully this is feasible in https://github.com/CohenCyril/nixpkgs/blob/master/pkgs/development/coq-modules/multinomials/default.nix ? (this way, as I said just now, it wouldn't require another change in multinomials.dev)

> But, if you confirm that the Nix packaging need not enabling the `-native-compiler yes` option, a simple solution could be to replace the `./configure` Nix build step with just `cp -f src/dune.in src/dune`

I guess native compilation with dune didn't get any serious testing in nix. Meanwhile, I'd rather be in favor of your solution (this configure script being already a workaround for a dune deficiency anyway).

discussion.author: JasonGross
discussion.comment:
I think I need @herbelin 's help in how to factor notations so that they work:
```coq
Require Import Coq.Lists.List.
Declare Scope seq_scope.
Open Scope seq_scope.
Notation "[ 'seq' E | i <- s ]" := (map (fun i => E) s)
  (at level 0, E at level 99, i binder,
   format "[ '[hv' 'seq'  E '/ '  |  i  <-  s ] ']'") : seq_scope.
Check [seq ?[F] i | i <- ?[enum] ?[P] ].
Reserved Notation "[ 'seq' F | x : T ]"
  (at level 0, F at level 99, x ident,
   format "'[hv' [ 'seq'  F '/ '  |  x  :  T ] ']'").
Check [seq ?[F] i | i <- ?[enum] ?[P] ].
(* Error: Syntax error: ':' expected after [name] (in [term]). *)
```

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: Hi @JasonGross @herbelin any hope to make this PR go forward?

discussion.author: herbelin
discussion.comment:
Hi,

At first view, supporting `[ 'seq' E | i <- s ]` with `i` a binder would require to change `x` to `binder` also in `[ 'seq' F | x : T ]` but the latter does not seem easy to generalize because the `x : T` has apparently a more complex interpretation than just being a binder, see the `in pred_of_simpl (@pred_of_argType T)` part (what would go wrong actually by replacing this part with `fun x : T => true`, in which case we would get the generalization easily?).

Assuming that there is no easy way to reformulate `pred_of_simpl (@pred_of_argType T)` under a form referring to `x : T` rather than to only `T`, what could be tried is to only add `[ 'seq' E | ' i <- s ]` with `i` pattern, rather than generalizing `[ 'seq' E | i <- s ]` to `i` binder.

Hoping that it helps.

discussion.author: herbelin
discussion.comment: @CohenCyril: we would need your help to know if there is a way to reformulate `pred_of_simpl (@pred_of_argType T)` under a form referring to `x : T` rather than to only `T` in notation `[ 'seq' F | x : T ] := [seq F | x : T in pred_of_simpl (@pred_of_argType T)]`.

discussion.author: JasonGross
discussion.comment:
> reformulate `pred_of_simpl (@pred_of_argType T)` under a form referring to `x : T` rather than to only `T` in notation

@herbelin What about using the `match` trick for substitution to do `(fun A (a : A) => A) _ (x : T))` in a way that does not leave a beta redex?  (I can code up a solution that does this the next time I'm at a computer; I don't have in my head an accurate model of which zeta-redexs unification will unfold and in what order, when it needs to perform evar unification.)

discussion.author: herbelin
discussion.comment:
> @herbelin What about using the `match` trick for substitution to do `(fun A (a : A) => A) _ (x : T))` in a way that does not leave a beta redex? (I can code up a solution that does this the next time I'm at a computer; I don't have in my head an accurate model of which zeta-redexs unification will unfold and in what order, when it needs to perform evar unification.)

I don't know if that'll work. We need `x : T` to occur in position of binder so that when substituted with something such as `'pat` it continues to make sense,

discussion.author: JasonGross
discussion.comment:
> We need `x : T` to occur in position of binder so that when substituted with something such as `'pat` it continues to make sense,

What about the equivalent of `(fun A (a : A -> True) => A) _ (fun x : T => I)`?

discussion.author: JasonGross
discussion.comment: (Of course the `match` form will never be used for printing, I don't know if that is an issue)

discussion.author: JasonGross
discussion.comment:
> What about the equivalent of `(fun A (a : A -> True) => A) _ (fun x : T => I)`?

```coq
Notation "'type_of' x"
  := match _, (fun x => I) with
     | T, f
       => match match f return T -> True with f' => f' end with
          | _ => T
          end
     end
       (x binder, only parsing, at level 20).
Check type_of x : nat. (* nat *)
Check type_of '((x, y) : nat * nat). (* (nat * nat)%type *)
```

discussion.author: JasonGross
discussion.comment:
Two issues seem to arise:
1. This change is incompatible with Coq 8.11 and Coq 8.12.  With mathcomp be dropping support for these versions on master anytime soon?
2. multinomials fails with
```
File "./src/freeg.v", line 207, characters 37-38:
Error:
In environment
G : zmodType
K : choiceType
s : seq (G * K)
x : K
The term "x" has type "Choice.sort K" while it is expected to have type
 "(?A * ?B)%type".
```
at https://github.com/math-comp/multinomials/blob/200ef66f7f892814dc7b9254f4f23bc7f59de093/src/freeg.v#L207 which is
```coq
Definition predom s: seq K := [seq x.2 | x <- s].
```
with
```coq
Variable G : zmodType.
Variable K : choiceType.
Implicit Types s   : seq (G * K).
Implicit Types x y : K.
```

The issue is that Coq now infers `x : K` rather than `x : _ * _`.  There's an easy backwards-compatible fix of changing `x` to `v` on that line; is that acceptable?

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> 1. This change is incompatible with Coq 8.11 and Coq 8.12.  With mathcomp be dropping support for these versions on master anytime soon?

Coq 8.11 I think we can do it for the next release, for Coq 8.12 we might have to wait a few more month but eventually yes.

commits.author: JasonGross
commits.message:
Add notations for patterns in [seq ... ] notations

This allows syntax such as
```coq
Check [seq '(x, y) <- List.combine (List.seq 0 5) (List.seq 0 5) | x == y ].
Check [seq x + y | '(x, y) <- List.combine (List.seq 5 5) (List.seq 5 5) ].
```
to parse and print.

review_discussion.author: thery
review_discussion.comment:
This subsumes `divq_eq` in `rat.v`. Maybe removing `divq_eq` should be part of this PR. We could also borrow its proof that is  less cryptic 
```coq
Lemma divr_eq x y z t : y != 0 -> t != 0 -> (x / y == z / t) = (x * t == z * y).
Proof.
move=> x_neq0 y_neq0; rewrite -(inj_eq (@mulIf _ (y * t) _)) ?mulf_neq0 //.
by rewrite mulrA divfK // mulrCA divfK // [z * _ ]mulrC.
Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: thery
review_discussion.comment:
Maybe this is better
```coq
Lemma sqrtrV x : 0 <= x -> sqrt (x^-1) = (sqrt x)^-1.
Proof.
case: ltrgt0P => // [x_gt0 _|->]; last by rewrite !(invr0, sqrtr0).
have sx_neq0 : sqrt x != 0 by rewrite sqrtr_eq0 -ltNge.
apply: (mulfI sx_neq0).
by rewrite -sqrtrM !(divff, ltW, sqrtr1) // lt0r_neq0.
Qed.
```

review_discussion.comment: Shouldn't it actually be `eqr_div`?

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma connect_rev e : connect [rel x y | e y x] =2 [rel x y | connect e y x].
Proof.
suff crev e': subrel (connect [rel x y | e' y x]) [rel x y | connect e' y x].
```
I think this makes for a much more readable statement that is also shorter. Not sure whether there are any deep considerations regarding `[rel x y | ...]` vs `(fun x y => ...)`.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I'm not exactly trilled by this name. How about something that includes `connect_sym` such as `sym_connect_sym`?

review_discussion.author: hivert
review_discussion.comment:
Thanks for your careful rereading !

I agree with you concerning the readability. However, the `e^~` idiom seems to be the one used throughout the files (see e.g. lemmas  `rev_path`, `rev_cycle`, `rev_sorted` in `path.v`). I wrote the statement this way for consistency. I'm not sure if there is a coding convention here. Maybe the statement of the above lemmas should be fixed. Please tell me.

review_discussion.author: hivert
review_discussion.comment: Again, I've no clear idea of what would be a good name and would happily follow any guideline or community vote. Do you this this should be discussed on zulip or somewhere else ?

review_discussion.author: affeldt-aist
review_discussion.comment:
There is some information here https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
See "Naming conventions for lemmas". `sym_connect_sym` indeed seems closer to the pattern
`(condition_)?mainSymbol_suffixes`.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Maybe `symmetric_connect_sym` to be closer to this pattern? (but I'm bad at names)

review_discussion.author: hivert
review_discussion.comment:
If we follow `ssrfun.v` then `sym_connect_sym` seem to be the right name. See eg
```
sym_left_transitive
     : forall (T : Type) (R : rel T),
       symmetric R -> transitive R -> left_transitive R
```

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I don't know whether there is a deeper reason. Maybe @CohenCyril or @gares know, this may date back a while. Note that `same_connect_rev` was already using the IMHO more readable `(fun x y => e y x)`. It may simply be, that all those lemmas predate the `[rel _ _ | _]` notation.

review_discussion.author: hivert
review_discussion.comment: I'm waiting a little if there is some input here and Integrate the fix if nothing happens.
