discussion.author: mgbedmar
discussion.comment: We've made a general cleanup following your guidelines and we believe the code could be ready now. Let us know if you have any other suggestions.

discussion.author: mgbedmar
discussion.comment:
> Also, please do not merge 'master' into PRs, instead please crate pull requests from branches that you can freely modify (i.e., usually something other than master) and then just rebase onto master, squashing intermediate commits in the process.

Sorry about that. We're not sure of completely understanding the protocol you just described. Can you confirm that the following steps would fix the current PR?

1. Create another branch `ed-hermoreyes:subchain` with all the commits we've made until now.
2. Re-establish the state of `ed-hermoreyes:master` to be as `math-comp:master`. 
3. Modify this PR so that it goes "into `math-comp:master` from `ed-hermoreyes:subchain`".
4. Rebase squashing all our commits to `ed-hermoreyes:subchain` into a single one.
5. Do 4 each time we request review.

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment:
> Sorry about that. We're not sure of completely understanding the protocol you just described. Can you confirm that the following steps would fix the current PR?

No problem. I think this looks like a sound process to fix the current PR, although I do not know how to change the "from" branch for an existing PR in GitHub. 

To be on the safe side, it may be a good idea to implement the changes I proposed before rebase squashing everything. Also, it's not necessary to squash for every review cycle, doing this once when things are (almost) stable can make the the review process more understandable. In the meantime, it may be necessary to rebase (without squashing) in order to resolve conflicts and make the CI run.  In any case, I would suggest only pushing commits you actually want to be reviewed, as every push triggers an email to every member of the core team and a lengthy CI pipeline.

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment:
I made a pass over the proofs, trying to find some synergies by reordering the lemmas. I hope you're fine with me committing directly to the branch of this PR (another reason why it's preferable to use something other than `master` for the source). I think there are more simplifications to be found. 

I removed `subchain_prefixP`, since the RHS of the disjunction subsumes the LHS. 

I still think that some lemmas can be removed, because they are merely compositions (by transitivity) of other lemmas, even though they are not necessarily proved that way currently. Maybe you can make another pass with this in mind.

discussion.author: mgbedmar
discussion.comment: We've been looking at the code. The changes you introduced are nice. Now, to be honest we don't have a clear idea of what the criterion is to decide what lemmas should be kept and which should be removed. The ones that have proofs that are merely compositions of two lemmas are `prefix_subchain` and `suffix_subchain`, but they also exist for `subseq`, so it doesn't feel quite right to remove them. Maybe you can give more concrete directives? Or just remove what you see fit, it's totally okay for you to make changes on the repo.

```suggestion
move => [s [s']]. case: s => //= [|x u].
```

```suggestion
  prefix s [:: x] = (s == [::]) || (s == [:: x]). 
Proof. by case: s => //= y s; rewrite prefixseq0 eqseq_cons. Qed.

Lemma subchain_singleton s x :

Proof. by rewrite /= prefix_singleton orbC orbA orbb. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I think these can be removed, as they are not needed to prove `take_prefix` and `drop_suffix`

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Fixpoint subchain_index s1 s2 :=
  if prefix s1 s2 then 0 
  else if s2 is y :: s2' then (subchain_index s1 s2').+1 else 1.
```
I think it is very unfortunate that the result `size s2` can be either the index of the empty subchain or the absence of any valid index. I suggest to change the definition as above, using the unambiguous `(size s2).+1` to signal "no valid index". This changes the lemmas slightly, mostly making them simpler (more expressive). For instance: 
```coq
Lemma subchain_indexseq0 s : subchain_index s [::] = (s != [::]).
Proof. by rewrite /= prefixseq0; case (_ == _). Qed.

Lemma subchain_index_ltn s1 s2 : 
  subchain s1 s2 = (subchain_index s1 s2 < (size s2).+1).
Proof. 
elim: s2 s1 => [|x s2' IH /=] s1; first by rewrite /= prefixseq0; case s1.
by case: (prefix _ _); rewrite IH !ltnS.
Qed.
```

discussion.author: eupp
discussion.comment:
@CohenCyril thank you for the thoughtful review. 

I've added `card_bseq` lemma. The proof of this lemma utilizes injectivity of `bseq_tagged_tuple` and `tagged_tuple_bseq`. 
The proof of infectivity for `tagged_tuple_bseq` is a bit clumsy because of dependent pairs' trickery and might be a subject to simplification. 

Regarding the usefulness of `bseq_of_seq`. I took it from `infotheo`, so it is better to ask @affeldt-aist whether we should keep it. 
Nevertheless, I've added lemma `size_bseq_of_seq : size (bseq_of_seq n s) <= size s.`

I've rechecked other lemmas for `n.-tuple T`. It looks like these lemmas are mostly about `thead`, `tnth`, etc. 
These definitions do not have equivalents for `n.-bseq T`, because bounded sequences have weaker guarantees on the length of sequences, in particular, they do not guarantee non-emptiness.

I've also updated the docs and changelog.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
The canonical declaration subsumes the previous lemma:
```coq
Canonical bseq_subType := Eval hnf in [subType for bseqval].

Lemma bseqval_inj : injective bseqval. Proof. exact: val_inj. Qed.
```

So one can simply omit it.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
apply/leq_trans; last exact/(size_bseq bs).
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Definition bseq_of_seq n T (s : seq T) : n.-bseq T := insubd [bseq] s.
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
This can be replaced by an encoding to tagged tuples:
```suggestion
Definition bseq_tagged_tuple {n T} (s : n.-bseq T) : {k : 'I_n.+1 & k.-tuple T} :=
  Tagged _ (in_tuple s : (Ordinal (size_bseq s : size s < n.+1)).-tuple _).

Definition tagged_tuple_bseq {n T} (t : {k : 'I_n.+1 & k.-tuple T}) : n.-bseq T :=
  widen_bseq (leq_ord (tag t)) (tagged t).
  
Lemma bseq_tagged_tupleK n T : cancel (@bseq_tagged_tuple n T) tagged_tuple_bseq.
Proof. by move=> t; apply/val_inj. Qed.

Definition bseq_finMixin n (T : finType) :=
  CanFinMixin (@bseq_tagged_tupleK n T).
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Add some theory of `widen_bseq`:
```suggestion

Definition widen_bseq m n T (lemn : m <= n) (bs : m.-bseq T) : n.-bseq T := 
  @Bseq n T bs (leq_trans (size_bseq bs) lemn).

Lemma widen_bseq_id n T (lenn : n <= n) (t : n.-bseq T) : widen_bseq lenn t = t.
Proof. exact: val_inj. Qed.

Lemma widen_bseqK m n T (lemn : m <= n) (lenm : n <= m) :
   cancel (@widen_bseq m n T lemn) (widen_bseq lenm).
Proof. by move=> t; apply: val_inj. Qed.

Lemma widen_bseq_trans m n p T (lemn : m <= n) (lenp : n <= p) (t : m.-bseq T) :
  widen_bseq (leq_trans lemn lenp) t = widen_bseq lenp (widen_bseq lemn t).
Proof. exact/val_inj. Qed.

Definition in_bseq T (s : seq T) : (size s).-bseq T := Bseq (leqnn (size s)).

Lemma in_nseqE T s : in_bseq s = s :> seq T. Proof. by []. Qed.

Lemma widen_bseq_in_bseq n T (t : n.-bseq T) :
  widen_bseq (size_bseq t) (in_bseq t) = t.
Proof. exact: val_inj. Qed.
```

The fact that `destruct k_eq` works surprises me though... @gares If you have any insight on this, I'd like to know. Also I was wondering were we were wrt the automatic selection of unifiable occurences of an index, is it implemented for `destruct` and that would be why it works (or is it just an accident)?

@vbgl / @maximedenes / @zimmi48 please help, I'm completely clueless about this CI failure...
To reproduce:
```bash
cd $(mktemp -d)
git clone https://github.com/math-comp/multinomials -b nix-toolbox && cd multinomials
nix-build
```
Note that `note nix-shell --run "./configure && make"` works :confused:

discussion.author: vbgl
discussion.comment:
The multinomials package is broken: the new `configure` script (recently added by Erik) refers to `/usr/bin/env` that is not available in the CI environment.

Below is a possible patch. (You may also set `dontConfigure = true;` to skip the failing configuration phase.)

~~~
diff --git a/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix b/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix
index 1c62b70..64b4945 100644
--- a/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix
+++ b/.nix/coq-overlays/multinomials/default.nix
@@ -33,6 +33,10 @@ with lib; mkCoqDerivation {
 
   useDune2ifVersion = v: versions.isGe "1.5.3" v || v == "dev";
 
+  preConfigure = ''
+    patchShebangs configure
+  '';
+
   propagatedBuildInputs =
     [ mathcomp.ssreflect mathcomp.algebra mathcomp-finmap mathcomp-bigenough ];
 
~~~

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Great contribution.
Please do not use `Program`

review_discussion.author: strub
review_discussion.comment:
> Please do not use `Program`

May I ask why? (This is a genuine question, as i find useful to use `Program` in that particular case)

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Sure, there is a tactic which is automatically used after `Next Obligation` which introduces some variables in the context with an automatic name, independently of the variables before the`:` in the statement. This is unstable.
One can also write `Obligation Tactic := idtac.` but then, no introduction at all, even for the variables before `:` in the statement, which you must then reintroduce for every single obligation.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: Also `Program Definition` may fill some obligations automatically (I do not know whether this is dependent or not on the `Obligation Tactic`) and I think it could use an axiom doing so...

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: I would love a deterministic alternative to `Program`, but never took the time to complain (I try to focus my complaining on other things :laughing: )

commits.author: ejgallego
commits.message:
[bigop] Add lemma for boolean enumeration in bigops

In some cases, such as in the proof in [1], when we have a bigop
over the boolean enumeration, we need to open the implementation
internals which is not optimal and moreover fragile.

We instead provide a helper lemma that expands a bigop over the
booleans with a concrete enumeration, and which is more
straightforward to use than `big_enumP`.

Note we require commutativity of the operator, this is to safeguard
against changes on the low-level `bool_enumP` enumeration.

[1] https://github.com/math-comp/analysis/blob/7b53e30b53b96e5eb3cabe476b0191353191b52c/theories/altreals/distr.v#L336

Co-authored-by: Amel Kebbouche <akebbouc@outlook.fr>

review_discussion.comment:
I think this should be replaced by `col1` and `colE` and put next to `row1` and `rowE`:
```coq
Lemma col1 (R : ringType) [n : nat] (i : 'I_n) : col i (1 : R)%:M = delta_mx i 0.
Proof. by apply/colP => j; rewrite !mxE eqxx andbT. Qed.

Lemma colE [R : ringType] [m n : nat] (i : 'I_n) (A : 'M[R]_(m, n)) :
  col i A = A *m delta_mx i 0.
Proof.
apply/colP=> j; rewrite !mxE (bigD1_ord i) //= mxE !eqxx mulr1.
by rewrite big1 ?addr0 // => i'; rewrite mxE /= lift_eqF mulr0.
Qed.
```
The theorem then follows from: `rewrite col1 -colE`.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Cut and generalize:
```suggestion
Lemma block_diag_mx_unit (R : comUnitRingType) n1 n2 
      (Aul : 'M[R]_n1) (Adr : 'M[R]_n2) :
   (block_mx Aul 0 0 Adr \in unitmx) = (Aul \in unitmx) && (Adr \in unitmx).
Proof. by rewrite !unitmxE det_ublock unitrM. Qed.

Lemma invmx_block_diag (R : comUnitRingType) n1 n2
      (Aul : 'M[R]_n1) (Adr : 'M[R]_n2) :
  block_mx Aul 0 0 Adr \in unitmx ->
  invmx (block_mx Aul 0 0 Adr) = block_mx (invmx Aul) 0 0 (invmx Adr).
Proof.
move=> /[dup] Aunit; rewrite block_diag_mx_unit => /andP[Aul_unit Adr_unit].
rewrite -[LHS]mul1mx; apply: (canLR (mulmxK _)) => //.
rewrite [RHS](mulmx_block (invmx Aul)) !(mulmx0, mul0mx, add0r, addr0).
by rewrite !mulVmx// -?scalar_mx_block.
Qed.
```

Sorry, my bad. Indeed, instances for products are defined after the `GRing` module.

Could you investigate the breakage in separable.v? I guess you have to add some explicit patterns to specify subterms to rewrite.

> > Also, this is a missing piece to support product rings in [algebra-tactics](https://github.com/math-comp/algebra-tactics). Thanks!
> 
> I don't understand what you mean here (and know very little about tactic programming)...

Nevermind. I just wanted to show my support for this PR. But here are some details in the case you are interested in it: the algebra-tactics library provides ring and field tactics (as in Coq) for MathComp with a work-in-progress feature to support morphisms, e.g., it can prove `f ((x + y) ^+ 2) = f x ^+ 2 + f y ^+ 2 + f x * f y *+ 2` automatically, where `f` is a ring morphism to a `comRingType`. By relying on this feature and the canonical instances added by this PR, it should also be able to prove equations on product rings involving `fst`, `snd`, and `pair`.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
After all, I investigated this by myself. The source of the failure here was that it unifies `(u ^ at_t, v ^ at_t).1` with a morphism application and then triggers a canonical structure resolution. Without the morphism instances for `fst`, it unfolds `fst` to obtain `u ^ at_t` and finds the fact that `map_poly` is a morphism, but this behavior changes in presence of the morphism instances for `fst`. So `simpl` before `rewrite -!rmorphM` would be enough here:
```suggestion
  by rewrite /= -!rmorphM -rmorphD Dr /= map_polyC polyC_eqp1.
```

Without the morphism instances for `fst`, it unfolds `fst` to obtain `u ^ at_t` and finds the fact that `map_poly` is a morphism, but this behavior changes in presence of the morphism instances for `fst`. So `simpl` before `rewrite -!rmorphM` would be enough here:

Thanks for the investigation and the explanation. I just applied your change (squashing the fix in a single commit) and (force) pushed. That should do the job.

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message:
Fix some inheritance issues

- The way `hierachy.ml` recognizes inheritance has been changed: `S1` inherits
  from `S2` when there is a coercion path from `S1.sort` to `S2.sort` and there
  is a canonical structure instance that unifies `S1.sort` and `S2.sort`,
  regardless of where (which module) these constants are declared.
  As a result, it recognizes non-forgetful inheritance and checks the uniqueness
  of join and exhaustiveness of canonical declarations involving it.
- `finFieldType` now inherits from `countDecFieldType`. This should probably be
  done with forgetful inheritance and a factory, but it remains non-forgetful
  inheritance for now.
- Get rid of a workaround in `ssrnum` thanks to the improvement of
  `hierarchy.ml`.


review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: @proux01 best practice is to use `have [] := view` instead of `case` for these. Also the choice of `view` is subtle, `eqP` is seldom used. We prefer `eqVneq`, `ifP`, `ifPn`, `ltgtP` and suff like that. Last resort is usually `boolP` or `(altP reflection_lemma)` (where `reflection_lemma` can be `eqP`).

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Another best practice -- rather than assembling the hypotheses like you did -- is to either
- rewrite the goal like I did (backward reasonning)
- or make `have : intermediate_statement` (forward reasoning) and switch back to backward reasoning inside the subgoal,

Massaging hypothesis should be done with parsimony as it clutters the proof script slightly more than the above techniques. (and it should rather be from complicated to simple)

If you're upset about the extra assumption, here is another possibility:
```coq
Lemma sorted_cat s1 s2 : sorted leT (s1 ++ s2) -> sorted leT s1 /\ sorted leT s2.
Proof.
by move: s1 s2 => [|x s1] [|y s2] //=; rewrite ?cats0 // cat_path /= => /and3P[].
Qed.

Lemma sorted_take n s : sorted leT s -> sorted leT (take n s).
Proof. by rewrite -[s in sorted _ s](cat_take_drop n) => /sorted_cat[]. Qed.

Lemma sorted_drop n s : sorted leT s -> sorted leT (drop n s).
Proof. by rewrite -[s in sorted _ s](cat_take_drop n) => /sorted_cat[]. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
This has nothing to do with sorting or ordering. If it is to be kept at all, it should be moved after `rcons_path` as:
```coq
Lemma path_take x p i : path x p -> path x (take i p).
Proof. by rewrite -{1}[p](cat_take_drop i) cat_path => /andP[->]. Qed.
```
@CohenCyril I'm never quite sure about the naming conventions for `path` lemmas (e.g., `cat_path` or `rcons_path`). So should this be `path_take` or `take_path?`.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Should be `take_path` (well spotted @chdoc).
Indeed unary predicates usually come as a suffix in mathcomp conventions, one can argue whether `path` is unary or binary, but the rest of the library seems to consider `x` as simply an accessory parameter and the only real parameter is `p`.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: should be `cat_sorted`

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: Should be `take_sorted` and `drop_sorted`

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: Shouldn't there actually also be an `E` somewhere (e.g. `cat_sortedE`) since the name refers to the shape of the premise rather than the conclusion?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
@chdoc you are right about the fact this one is misnamed..., I was a bit too eager in my renaming suggestions.
It would not matter so much if there wasn't a possibly better candidate for being named `cat_sorted`, namely
```coq
Lemma cat_sorted x y s1 s2 (s1x := rcons s1 x) (ys2 := y :: s2) :
  sorted leT s1x ys2 = [&& x <= y, sorted leT s1x & sorted leT ys2].
```

However `E` lemma are usually "elimination equation" lemmas (taking a symbol to an equivalent definition), this is not the case here, so `car_sortedE` would also be misnamed

In this light, I suggest we'd rather name it `cat_sorted2` to signify both (2) sides of the `cat` are sorted, or that we keep `sorted_cat` even thought the name does not respect usual conventions.

discussion.author: ejgallego

> Last figure I remember was nearly a factor two but @gares would know better.

A 2x increase in compilation time seems a bit surprising (and maybe worrying) . In particular, the amount of time spent in HB code should be just a small fraction of the compilation time.

Isn't that suspicious? What is the main bottleneck here.

I think that Coq really needs something like HB, but if users are gonna get a 2x slowdown from it I'm not sure it is ready until it is more optimized.

discussion.author: gares

The difference is that structures are more regular than before, and less manual tweaks. The time spent in HB commands is negligible, or close to so. The code generated is more likely to trigger bad behavior in conversion heuristics. But so far every time I did investigate a little change here or there would change the cost of a few lines of 100x, so I'm not scared, it is just about spending time on it.
And for now the (little) energy is in cover the whole ssrnum (not far, but not there yet).

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Why don't we remove (or keep) the phantom parameter everywhere? This `apply` does not respect the uniform inheritance condition, and type-checking terms like `RMorphism.apply _ f` (where `f` has type `{rmorphism R -> S}`) leaves the phantom argument as a unification variable.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: The phantom parameter is indeed removed, this apply thing is only meant for some backward compatibility purpose. Maybe should it be deprecated?

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Now I see that `RMorphism.apply` is just a compat layer and not really used (except for Algebra Tactics). But, `RMorphism.map` is used in the definition of the `{rmoprhism R -> S}` notation below.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: I guess we could change the notation from `{additive fUV }` to `{additive U -> V }` with appropriate levels for `U` and `V` without breaking much, but introducing this intermediary `map` just sounds easier.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: That should indeed be possible, but `U` and `V` will be more verbose than before (which is an obvious downside of reverse coercions compared to phantom types).

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Indeed, so we should probably keep it as it is.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Then, I think we should also have the phantom parameter in the record type `RMorphism.type`. I will try to produce an example supporting this claim.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
I managed to produce only a very artificial example, but this shows that we can lose nice notations like `{additive _}` by insertion of coercion:
```coq
From mathcomp Require Import all_ssreflect all_algebra.

Section S.

Variables (R S : ringType) (f : {rmorphism R -> S}).

Goal False.
match constr:(GRing.raddfD f) with
  | GRing.raddfD ?f =>
    let ty := type of f in idtac ty
end.
(*
In MathComp 1.15:
{additive R -> S}
In MathComp 2.0:
(GRing.Additive.type R S)
*)
Abort.

End S.
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Maybe we could add an only printing notation? (but at this point it might be better to craft an actual notation for `{additive R -> S}` not using the phantom type)

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
Also, unification does not propagate the phantom parameter.
```coq
Goal False.
evar (R' : zmodType).
evar (S' : zmodType).
evar (ph : phant (?R' -> ?S')).
evar (f' : @Additive.map ?R' ?S' ?ph).
unify (GRing.Additive.sort ?f') (GRing.RMorphism.sort f).
(*
  ph := ?ph : phant (R -> S)
  f' := f : Additive.map (U:=R) (V:=S) ?ph
  ============================
*)
```

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: Ok, I'll try the notation without phantom type.

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment: @pi8027 I modified the notation to remove the phantom type (or rather, use the ones provided by HB).

review_discussion.author: proux01
review_discussion.comment:
Unfortunately, it doesn't fix your above example since we now have:
```Coq
(GRing.Additive.type_ R S)
```
The only fix I can think of is the addition of an only printing notation:
```
Notation "{ 'additive' R -> S }" := (GRing.Additive.type_ R S) (only printing) : type_scope.
```
(note that then, we should also add a similar only printing notation for polynomials, matrices,...)
Not sure it's worth the effort.

commits.author: gares
commits.message:
Squash HB port

Commit messages prior to squash below:

Partial port to HB

A little less than half the structures have been ported: all of
`fingroup.v`, `presentation.v`, `morphism.v`, `ssralg.v`, `bigop.v`,
`ssrfun.v`, `seq.v`, `choice.v`, `binomial.v`, `ssreflect.v`, `div.v`,
`fintype.v`, `ssrbool.v`, `ssrnat.v`, `eqtype.v`, `tuple.v`,
`fingraph.v`, `prime.v`, `path.v`, `finset.v`, `ssrnotations.v`,
`finfun.v`, `ssrmatching.v` have been ported, including 36 structures.

A third of `order.v` has been ported so far, and `generic_quotient.v`,
`ssrAC.v` and `perm.v` are waiting to be ported: they are the files
that `make` fails on and are blocking for all the files that are not
mentioned above. There may be missing features in HB to address them
properly but no way to identify these missing features precisely
without doing the porting. Moreover since multiple failures occur in
parallel their is a potential for multiple groups to work at the same
time. Hence we suggest to have a porting sprint.

Co-Auhtored-By: Cyril Cohen <cyril.cohen@inria.fr>
Co-Authored-By: Kazuhiko Sakaguchi <pi8027@gmail.com>

Big refactoring

- new convention: mixins are named `${PreRequsite}_Is${Addentum}`
    e.g. + `IsZmodule` (no prerequisite)
         + `Zmodule_IsRing` (Zmodule as a prerequisite, completing to Ring)
- new type aliases `sub_type`, `inj_type`, `can_type` and `pcan_type`
  which are automatically canonical and which can be used in combination
  with `Structure.Build` (as in `Structure.Build mytype (sub_type mytype`)
  to copy instances that are canonical on the alias, to the type itseld.
- New notations [`Equality of ... <:]`, `[HasDecEq of _ ... <:]`, etc
  to replace `[eqMixin of ... <:]`, etc
- removed many detours due to bugs in HB that have been fixed now...

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: To make sure these lemmas are not misnamed, let's summon @CohenCyril anyway.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Proof. by case: (intP m). Qed.
```
or
```suggestion
Proof. by rewrite abszE ler_norm. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
I think that the following lemma could substitute the use of the above lemmas:
```coq
Goal forall (R : numDomainType) (i : int), `|i|%:R = `|i|%:~R :> R.
Proof. by move=> R i; rewrite -abszE. Qed.
```
or, more generally
```coq
Goal forall (R : numDomainType) (x : R) (i : int), x *+ `|i| = x *~ `|i|.
Proof. by move=> R x i; rewrite -abszE. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: affeldt-aist
review_discussion.comment:
> I think that the following lemma could substitute the use of the above lemmas:

I have been told that we could have them all. @CohenCyril 
`xyz_norm` lemmas have easy-to-search names, whereas the generic ones look like low-level manipulation of notations.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Another issue is that `` `|_| `` in these statements are not `GRing.norm` but `absz` and thus their current names seem wrong. I think we could copy almost any lemma involving `GRing.norm` that applies to `int` in this way, but I'm not sure if that's what we want.

review_discussion.author: affeldt-aist
review_discussion.comment:
> Another issue is that `` `|_| `` in these statements are not `GRing.norm` but `absz` and
> thus their current names seem wrong.

Indeed, but the name `gez0_abs` is already taken :-/. To me, the "_norm" prefix looked appropriate
for a lemma intended to be used with a `numDomainType`.

> I think we could copy almost any lemma involving `GRing.norm` that applies to `int` in this way,
> but I'm not sure if that's what we want.

Indeed. Rewriting with `gez0_abs` in a context with `numDomainType` still looks cumbersome to me though.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
If you point me out where you need these lemmas, I will try to propose a fix for that.

@CohenCyril What do you think?

review_discussion.author: affeldt-aist
review_discussion.comment:
These lemmas are used in https://github.com/math-comp/analysis/blob/lebesgue_measure/theories/measure_wip.v.

NB: they are part of code under refactoring.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: In both these lemmas, the LHS is about `abs` not `norm`, moreover the name for the operation `*+` is `natmul` and the shape `mulr*n` or `mulrn*` is wildely use for lemmas about this (e.g. `mulrIn`) and for `%:R` it is `natr` (as in `natrD` etc), so I'd pick the following names: `mulr_absz` and `natr_absz`.

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment: I just pushed some more simplifications (mainly the proof of `partition_pigenhole`); made use of the brand new `/[! _ ]` feature. I also chose to deprecate `bigcup_disjoint`, because it is merely one direction of the new `bigcup_disjointP` view lemma. Are such deprecations added to the CHANGELOG? If so, where?

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment: Fixed, and rebased/squashed.

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment: @affeldt-aist , @CohenCyril, is there something left to be done, or can someone press the merge button?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma bigcup_disjoint U P F :
```
I'd keep it, because it allows for `rewrite bigcup_disjoint`, which has no equivalent with `bigcup_disjointP`, unless you had a 3-step renaming in mind?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
  (forall i : I, J i -> B i != set0) -> partition P (cover P) /\ {in J &, injective B}.
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
move=> P disjB inhB; have s0NP : set0 \notin P.
```

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I'm not sure I agree with this. If one adds the "customary implicits" (`Arguments bigcup_disjointP {T I U P F}.`) then `rewrite bigcup_disjoint` can be replaced by `rewrite (introT bigcup_disjointP)`. Without it one needs some parentheses and `_`. So in the unlikely case that this is really desirable, it can be done. And doesn't this argument apply to almost all reflection lemmas?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: This equations looks to me like it should be the other way around

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: Same (other way around?)

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: Hmm, I agree, but @affeldt-aist already merged this. :flushed:

review_discussion.author: affeldt-aist
review_discussion.comment: My bad. Maybe a new, small fix-PR?

Update mathcomp/ssreflect/path.v

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: I will port some more lemmas from [coq-stablesort](https://github.com/pi8027/stablesort) which is another library dedicated to stability proofs of sort and highly optimized sorting algorithms. (It will take some more time I guess.)

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: In line with the lemmas above, I think these should be named `relI_*` (rather than `*_relI`) and stated in the converse direction. Should we introduce some notation for relI, (e.g., `[relI e1 & e2]`)?

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I think this should be `cat_nilp`, as `nilp` is a unary predicate. The same holds for `nilp_rev` below. (I'm not a fan of the special convention for unary predicates, but that's a different discussion).

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
> In line with the lemmas above, I think these should be named `relI_*` (rather than `*_relI`)

I don't think so: https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/blob/57af89f67dc3ace1a35fdfdbf32be309e20f0108/mathcomp/ssreflect/seq.v#L647-L660

> and stated in the converse direction.

Sure.

> Should we introduce some notation for relI, (e.g., `[relI e1 & e2]`)?

Probably, yes.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
I don't understand why you point to `all` here, which is a binary predicate. `CONTRIBUTING.md` states:
- `naryPredicate_mainSymbol+`
- `mainSymbol_unaryPredicate`
Summoning @CohenCyril

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Well, one can argue whether `sorted` and `path` are really unary and `all` binary . We tend to consider them as following the unary convention in the main argument (the list), but the binary relation plays the same role as the unary predicate in `all`.

I agree the direction should be the converse one indeed (as for `all`).

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: Why don't you use `[rel xy | ...]`? I wonder whether we should add `[relI r & r' ]`...

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: Isn't `[rel x y | ...]` is only for homogeneous relations?

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: Well, while I am not exactly a fan of the special convention for unary predicates, but I would prefer if new names were in line with preexisting names. So that means defaulting to `<main_symbol>_path`, as with the other path lemmas. Indeed, I tend to think of path as unary, where the relation should be inferable from the context and the sequence is nonempty. Even more so for sorted. But with "for all" neither the domain nor the predicate is a natural candidate for being implicit or inferable from the context.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
I'm not 100% fan of the special convention for unary predicates either, especially when the predicate is only unary through certain lenses... However, the convention is definitely pervasive and I'm afraid it would affect even more loc than #733 itself, not to mention power users neurons... :smile:

In other `path` lemmas' name  `<main_symbol>_path`, `<main_symbol>` refers to the path sequence argument, not the relation argument. Note that before this PR, AFAICT only `merge_path` and `map_path` do follow this convention, while `path_mask` and `path_filter` are breaking it... we should fix them (in another PR).

What I meant but maybe failed to convey is that, for me, the fact that the `<main_symbol>` is on the relation argument is a good enough reason to switch to the n+2-ary convention in the current case.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: Ah yes you are right, ... such a shame though... maybe we can add notations `{rel T}` for unary and `{rel T & T'}` for binary and generalize constructions and lemmas... probably not very important though...

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: The rule should be flipped

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Done. Shall we open a new issue for `rel`?

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: I have no strong opinion on this point but agree with the last paragraph by Cyril. Since these lemmas reason about two different graphs `e` and `e'`, `path` can be seen as a binary predicate in this particular case.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: Indeed, the naming of the path lemmas is not as consistent as one would hope, but that's another issue. I agree that it's hard to justify using the "unary predicate" convention for the cases where the main symbol is not within the "main" argument of a pseudo-unary predicate. So changing the direction is probably sufficient here.

commits.author: CohenCyril
commits.message:
Adding big block matrices

- with special cases for row, column, and diagonal matrices
- we define an order bijection between the indexing of the whole matrix
  and the indexing of the blocks to preserve triangularity

commits.author: CohenCyril
commits.message:
Big refactoring

- new convention: mixins are named ${PreRequsite}_Is${Addentum}
    e.g. + `IsZmodule` (no prerequisite)
         + `Zmodule_IsRing` (Zmodule as a prerequisite, completing to Ring)
- new type aliases `sub_type`, `inj_type`, `can_type` and `pcan_type`
  which are automatically canonical and which can be used in combination
  with `Structure.Build` (as in `Structure.Build mytype (sub_type mytype`)
  to copy instances that are canonical on the alias, to the type itseld.
- New notations [`Equality of ... <:]`, `[HasDecEq of _ ... <:]`, etc
  to replace `[eqMixin of ... <:]`, etc
- removed many detours due to bugs in HB that have been fixed now...

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message: Fix `\meet^p` and `\join^p` notations and the scope of n.-tuplelexi notation

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message:
Redefine the lattice structure with fewer axioms

that also eliminate the interaction between meet and join, so that it can also
be redefined as the join of meet-semilattice and join-semilattice structures
without extra mixin.

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message:
Add some order structures and implement definitionally involutive duals

- Add meet and join semilattice structures
- Add some order structures with a top but without a bottom
- T^d^d is definitionally equal to T where T is an ordered type instance

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message:
Add some more order structures

- The following order structures have been added:
  + `(b|t|tb)OrderType`,
  + `fin(B)MeetSemilatticeType`, and
  + `fin(T)JoinSemilatticeType`.
- Since a finite lattice has lower and upper bounds if it is nonempty, the
  finite lattice structures `finLatticeType`, `finDistrLatticeType`,
  `finOrderType`, and `finCDistrLatticeType` were equipped with bounds before
  this change. They have been renamed to `finTBLatticeType`,
  `finTBDistrLatticeType`, `finTBOrderType`, and `finCTBDistrLatticeType` and
  the original ones except for `finCDistrLatticeType` have been redefined as
  possibly empty ones, which allows us, e.g., to make a finite ordinal `'I_n`
  a `finOrderType` for any `n`.

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message:
Refactor the order theory

- Refactor the order theory,
- Redefine `porderType` with fewer axioms, and
- Rename `(meet|join)SemilatticeMixin` to `(meet|join)Mixin`.

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message: Port the relorder library from Coq-Polyhedra/order

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message: Make instances for (T * T')^d definitionally equal to ones for T^d * T'^d

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message:
Arguments declarations for relorder inheritance

In addition:
- turn the relorder structures into primitive records, and
- fix the mixins and packagers accordingly.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
> Currently, `classfun.v` is broken since it uses `Cint`, but importing `ssrint` adds the infix `^` notation which collides with that of `group_scope`.

It seems that group notations and ring notations are mixed almost everywhere in `classfun.v`. So there is no other solution than adding `%g` whenever required. If a scope declaration for arguments of coercion to `Funclass` works, this situation probably becomes better. But this does not work in the current implementation of Coq (see https://github.com/coq/coq/issues/5527#issuecomment-568242128):
```coq
Arguments fun_of_cfun [gT] [B] _ _%g.
```

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: I guess `Qint` and `Qnat` should be deprecated and superseded by `Cint` and `Cnat` respectively. Right? @CohenCyril

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> I guess `Qint` and `Qnat` should be deprecated and superseded by `Cint` and `Cnat` respectively. Right? @CohenCyril

Yes! And `Cint` and `Cnat` should both be renamed `Num.int` and `Num.nat`.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> > I guess `Qint` and `Qnat` should be deprecated and superseded by `Cint` and `Cnat` respectively. Right? @CohenCyril
> 
> Yes! And `Cint` and `Cnat` should both be renamed `Num.int` and `Num.nat`.

And they should be in the mixin, so as to make the computations for `ssrint` and `rat` faster!

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
> > Yes! And `Cint` and `Cnat` should both be renamed `Num.int` and `Num.nat`.
> 
> And they should be in the mixin, so as to make the computations for `ssrint` and `rat` faster!

Make sense. Allowing the use of `Cint` without importing `ssrint` would also be nice to get a better fix for `classfun` and `inertia`. But reimplementing `Cint` theory in the absence of `ssrint` would require some more work.

discussion.author: pi8027
CohenCyril
pi8027
discussion.comment:
> Yes roughly, except the truncation has no reason to be only for non negative numbers, I would prefer the function in the mixin to be more general, knowing that there could be a factory providing opaque `trunc`, `is_nat`, and `is_int` from a `nat` upper bound.

The problem is that we have to relocate the basic part of `ssrint` (`int` and `intmul` at least?) to `ssrnum` (or `ssralg`?) in order to generalize the truncation to the negative case. Since the above mixin has been proved equivalent to `Num.archimedean_axiom`, we can provide such a factory.

> I had planned to wait for HB to make this kind of changes... I am a bit surprised you are willing to go through so much work while we intend to trivialize all of this...

Reworking an existing branch is easier to do now rather than later. Also, IMO actual difficulties appear in places other than the definitions of structures, as in the breakage of `classfun.v`.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: `Cnat`, `Cint`, `truncC`, and `floorC` have been renamed to `Num.nat`, `Num.int`, `Num.trunc`, and `floorR` respectively. I guess we have to relocate `ssrint.int` (or make the dependency from `ssrint` to `ssrnum` opposite) to rename `floorR` to `Num.floor` anyway.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: Almost done except that `floorR` is still not a part of the Archimedean mixin and defined in `ssrint`. I'm not sure what to do about this point.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
Here is a summary of possible solutions:
1. Keeping the dependency relation of libraries as is, placing `truncR`, `Rnat`, and `Rint` in `ssrnum`, and placing `floorR` in `ssrint` (the current situation):
   - Pros: This solution works.
   - Cons: `floorR` cannot be located in `ssrnum.Num` (we can declare another `Num` module in `ssrint` to work around this, but it seems troublesome). The `floorR` functions of `int` and `rat` cannot be as straightforward/efficient as we expect. The `archiNumDomainType` theory has to be separated into two parts (one in `ssrnum` and another in `ssrint`).
2. Keeping the dependency relation of libraries as is, but relocating `int` and `intmul` from `ssrint` to `ssrnum` or before to include `floorR` and related lemmas in `ssrnum`:
   I think this solution does not work, because statements and proofs of some lemmas about `floorR` require, e.g., canonical `ringType` and `orderType` instances of `int`. So we have to relocate a significant part of `ssrint` anyway.
3. Changing the dependency relation of libraries to make `ssrnum` requiring `ssrint`:
   This solution may work. But the canonical `numDomainType` of `int` has to be defined in `ssrnum` or later, and then some lemmas about `int` cannot be stated in `ssrint`, e.g., `abszE` which requires the norm function.
4. Adding another library that requires both `ssrnum` and `ssrint`, and relocating the Archimedean structures and related lemmas to it:
   I think this is the best solution among these, but requires at least two steps of transition.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: Yet another solution: dispatching the contents of ssrint between ssralg and ssrnum.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: @CohenCyril That is what I meant in solution 3 IIUC.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> @CohenCyril That is what I meant in solution 3 IIUC.

Indeed. It was not clear to me whether you were suggesting to remove the file ssrint, which is what I suggest here.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: Anyway, I like solution 4... it makes a lot of sense to me. How would you envision the transitiom though? Having files with new names required by files with old names?

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
> Indeed. It was not clear to me whether you were suggesting to remove the file ssrint, which is what I suggest here.

I did not suggest removing `ssrint.v`. So they are actually different. But, anyway...

> Anyway, I like solution 4... it makes a lot of sense to me. How would you envision the transitiom though? Having files with new names required by files with old names?

In the first step, we try to relocate definitions and lemmas about the Archimedean structures as much as possible, to a new file, say `archimedean.v`. Since we have to deprecate `Znat` and related lemmas in `ssrint`, we cannot relocate some of them. So we declare them as `Local` ones in `ssrnum` or `ssrint`, provide deprecation aliases if needed, and also provide non-deprecated aliases in `archimedean.v`. I think this trick is also applicable to definitions of structures. In the second step, we remove deprecation aliases and relocate everything that depends on `archiNumDomainType` to `archimedean.v`.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: The way I saw it was that `ssrnum.v` would be "fake file" `Require Export`ing `ssrnum_without_archimedean` (find a proper name e.g. just `num.v`) as well as `archimedean` so that there is no overlay to make for developments that used to depend in `ssrnum` but use archimedean structures.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
Currently, ssrnum.v defines both numeric and Archimedean structures, but some notations (e.g., archiNumDomainType) are deprecated there and re-exported from archimedean.v without deprecation. I also had to re-export the canonical declarations of closure properties of Num.nat and Num.int from rat.v and algC.v to fix the breakage (Cf the last commit).
Overlays are required to make hints working and they just insert a few simplifications. I will try to get rid of them if needed.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment: I have opened #692 to control the impact of this PR.

pi8027
discussion.comment: @proux01 That is missing and the `floor` function has to be redefined to prove it. I will do it before the next MathComp call. Thanks!

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
MathComp Analysis does not compile anymore with this change:
```coq
- File "./theories/reals.v", line 486, characters 8-39:
- Error:
- In environment
- R : realType
- x : R
- The term "- x" has type "GRing.Zmodule.sort R"
- while it is expected to have type "Num.ArchiNumDomain.sort ?R".
```
https://github.com/math-comp/analysis/blob/339401ed1e340428554fe1e9cd35e3ea5386bd85/theories/reals.v#L479-L486

It seems that there is no fix without adding an inheritance from `archiNumDomainType` to `realType`.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> It seems that there is no fix without adding an inheritance from `archiNumDomainType` to `realType`.

Indeed, would there be a problem to do so?

I believe this PR has no chance to be backward compatible unless we make the old and new codes coexist.
I.e. we would keep the old mixin and the old structure as such (keeping `ssrnum.v` intact) and add distinct incompatible mixins and new structures in `archimedean.v` that would be opt-in for now. In this setting there would be a hug difference between legacy code and new code. But maybe that would be ok.

We should discuss this in a mathcomp meeting.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment: @CohenCyril I think trying to be backward compatible is a bit painful in this case. Anyway, I agree that we should discuss this in a meeting. Meanwhile, I would like to revise the theory part of archimedean.v. (I have some questions and comments since I did not write everything by myself.)

discussion.comment: BTW, why CI disappeared from the checklist here?

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> BTW, why CI disappeared from the checklist here?

no idea, that's very strange

discussion.author: CohenCyril

review_discussion.author: gares
review_discussion.comment: yes!

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
You could provide a non opaque function instead e.g.
```coq
Definition floorR x :=
   if x >= 0 then trunc x else let n := trunc (- x) in if x == n%:R then - n%:Z else - n.-1%N.
```
That way we can still compute (e.g. in Q) without having all the functions in the interface...

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: @CohenCyril My plan is to extend the Archimedean mixin with the floor function in the next step (hopefully MathComp 1.14.0). So I would rather like to keep it opaque for now to prevent future breakages. For example, the floor function of `int` can simply be the identity function `fun n : int => n` which is inconvertible with your general floor function.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
I think we should
1. reformulate this lemma in terms of bigop over a list since it is the most general form of bigop, and
2. factor out the fact `(forall i, P i -> F i \is a Rnat) -> \sum_(i | P i) F i = (\sum_(i | P i) trunc (F i))%:R` as a lemma.

review_discussion.author: pi8027

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: These lemmas can be factored out to `x \is Rreal -> ceil x = floor x + (~~ (x \is a Rint))%:R`. This can probably be useful in some cases but I'm not sure.

review_discussion.author: pi8027

- the outcome in Coq 8.12 is `+`
```diff
 imset2Sr
-     : forall (aT aT2 rT : finType) (f2 : aT -> aT2 -> rT) 
-         (A B : {pred aT2}) (C : {pred aT}),
+     : forall (aT aT2 rT : finType) (f2 : aT -> aT2 -> rT)
+         (A B : predPredType aT2) (C : predPredType aT),
        A \subset B ->
        [set f2 x y | x in C, y in A] \subset [set f2 x y | x in C, y in B]
```
(cf [this CI build](https://gitlab.com/math-comp/math-comp/-/jobs/871480999))

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: I think the most use-cases of `all1rel` require `r` to be symmetric. This is the case at least in `all_comm_mx`, `ahom_in`, and `Derivation`. But, if it is not the case in general, I would like to put the suffix `_sym` to the names of these lemmas.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
I prefer `all2rel` ~or `pairwise`~ or **selfrel** than `all1rel`.
@gares, @chdoc, you participated in the first discussion on `allrel`, what do you say about this change and my suggestion?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: I'm a bit concerned that the proof looks longer...

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: I had the impression that the convention here was `l` `r` rather than positional (as in `allpairs0l`)

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: These lemma only make sense when the relation is symmetric anyway, otherwise it can all be obtained by `allrel_cons2` which would be the lemma combining `allrel_consr` and `allrel_consl`.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
rewrite allrel_cons2 => /and4P [xy' xs2 ys1 s1s2] /andP [hx xs1] /andP [hy ys2].
case: ifP => xy /=; rewrite (hx, hy) /=.
- by apply: ih1; rewrite ?allrel_consr ?ys1 //= xy xy' implybT.
- by apply: ih2; have:= leT_total x y; rewrite ?allrel_consl ?xs2 ?xy //= => ->.
```
introducing  `allrel_cons2` as in [a comment below](https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/665/files#r527593132)

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: PS: and maybe that's what shortens the proof of `merge_stable_path` once more, as I tried to exhibit in [another comment](https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/665/files#r527591337)

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion

Lemma allrel_cons2 x y xs ys :
  allrel (x :: xs) (y :: ys) = [&& r x y, all (r x) ys, all (r^~ y) xs & allrel xs ys].
Proof. by rewrite /= all_predI/= -andbA. Qed. (* or something like that *)

```

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: I think we should rather provide a multi-rule rewriting lemma consists of `allrel_(cons|cat)(l|r)`, etc.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
How about shortening the description to something along the lines of:
```suggestion
(* allrel r xs ys := all [pred x | all (r x) ys] xs                           *)
(*                == r x y holds whenever x is in xs and y is in ys           *)
```
I don't feel the need to use `proposition` here, as it it actually a boolean.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I'm in favor of the new definition, I wasn't fond of the `all id ...` to begin with. As to to the naming, don't have much to say.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
On second thoughts, I prefer to reserve `pairwise` for
```coq
Fixpoint pairwise {T} (r : rel T) (xs : seq T) :=
  if xs is x :: xs then all (r x) xs && pairwise r xs else true.
```

commits.author: CohenCyril
commits.message: Using Arguments / to deal with volatile definitions

discussion.author: gares
discussion.comment: Can you tell me why ! was not ok?

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
@gares
> Can you tell me why ! was not ok?

Almost all definitions (except for `eqseq`) which are involved in this tuning have at least one "default" case, where one argument does not need to be a constructor for a ground value to be output. e.g. in `take` if the list is `[::]`, then whatever the natural number, the output is `[::]`. The "right" criterion is that no match should be exposed by doing so.

Except for `mask` where there is an extra match on a boolean that we would like to expose. So I sacrificed expansion when the mask is `[::]` and not the list `s`, for the sake of still having a form of controlled expansion, which would still expose the match on the boolean.

This hints at the fact that both `!` and `nomatch` are too restrictive in different fashion. Somehow, we would like to say which `match` are allowed/forbidden instead. e.g. (wishful thinking) `Arguments mask _ !m !s : simpl nomatch`, *should* simplify iff it does not (directly) expose a match on `m` or `s`.

Moreover, in the current state, `nomatch` will prevent expansion even if the appearance of the match has nothing to do with the unfolding of the constant itself. e.g.
```coq
Definition mask_if mask b (x : T) m' s' :=  if b then x :: mask m' s' else mask m' s'
Fixpoint mask m s {struct m} :=
  match m, s with
  | b :: m', x :: s' => mask_if mask b x m' s'
  | _, _ => [::]
  end.
Arguments mask : simpl nomatch.
Arguments mask_if /.
```
will still not simplify `mask (b :: m) (x :: s)` because doing one loop of the fixpoint and then expanding `mask_if` will result in a match :cry: :cry: :cry:


review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: The problem here is that `filter_sort` has to use `sort_stable` for a `seq nat` obtained by the `mkseq` technique and it does not allow us to factor out some intermediate steps of them using a `Section`. Anyway, I managed to prove this lemma with fewer `have` in the last revision. Do you still see any possible improvement?

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
I'm not sure what you mean. My ideas were along the lines of:
```coq
Section LeLex.

Variables (T : Type) (leT : rel T) (x0 : T) (s : seq T).

Let leN := relpre (nth x0 s) leT.
Definition le_lex := [rel n m | leN n m && (leN m n ==> (n < m))].

Lemma le_lex_trans : transitive leT -> transitive le_lex.
Proof.
move=> leT_tr. rewrite /le_lex /leN => ? ? ? /= /andP [xy xy'] /andP [yz yz'].
rewrite (leT_tr _ _ _ xy yz); apply/implyP => zx; move: xy' yz'.
by rewrite (leT_tr _ _ _ yz zx) (leT_tr _ _ _ zx xy); apply: ltn_trans.
Qed.

Lemma le_lex_irr : irreflexive le_lex. 
Proof. by move=> x; rewrite /le_lex/leN/= ltnn implybF andbN. Qed.

End LeLex.

Arguments le_lex_trans [T leT] x0 s.

Lemma filter_sort T (leT : rel T) :
  total leT -> transitive leT ->
  forall p s, filter p (sort leT s) = sort leT (filter p s).
Proof.
move=> leT_total leT_tr p s; case Ds: s => // [x s1].
rewrite -{s1}Ds -(mkseq_nth x s) !(filter_map, sort_map); congr map.
have ? : total (relpre (nth x s) leT) by move=> n m; apply: leT_total.
have le_lex_tr := le_lex_trans x s leT_tr.
apply: (irr_sorted_eq le_lex_tr (le_lex_irr leT x s)). 
- exact/sorted_filter/sort_iota_stable. 
- exact/sort_stable/sorted_filter/iota_ltn_sorted/ltn_trans/ltn_trans.
- by move=> ?; rewrite !(mem_filter, mem_sort).
Qed.
```
I'm not sure `le_lex` is a good global name, but I think the pattern of turning an order on `T` into an corresponding order on `nat` is quite generic. I'm surprised this is only needed once...

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
@chdoc In your code above, `le_lex` is a combination of two things: 1. lexicographic ordering and 2. turning an order on elements of a sequence into a corresponding order on `nat` using `nth`. If I declare it globally, I would rather split it into these two parts and parameterize the former one to take two relations, but it would also make this proof script lengthy. So I would like to keep the current one for now.

A possible solution to this issue would be using canonical structures to infer properties of relations, but this should be another PR.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
I wasn't suggesting that my comment is the final version, but I am strongly in favor of making the constructions explicit. You're also proving totality of the `relpre`+`nth` construction twice (I know, it's a one-liner). Maybe @CohenCyril has an opinion on this; his review is still outstanding. 

Also, I'm not sure what's the connection to "lexicographic ordering", which I understand as the extension of an order from a type to sequences/words over that type, as done in dictionaries. But maybe that term is ambiguous.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Let lt_lex := [rel n m | leN n m && (leN m n ==> (n < m))].
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
    sorted lt_lex s && perm_eq s (iota (size (flatten ss')) (size s)) &&
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
  push_invariant (s1 :: ss) -> sorted lt_lex (merge_sort_pop leN s1 ss).
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma sort_iota_stable n : sorted lt_lex (sort leN (iota 0 n)).
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
pose lt_lex := [rel n m | leN n m && (leN m n ==> (n < m))].
have lt_lex_tr: transitive lt_lex.
  rewrite /lt_lex /leN => ? ? ? /= /andP [xy xy'] /andP [yz yz'].
  rewrite (leT_tr _ _ _ xy yz); apply/implyP => zx; move: xy' yz'.
  by rewrite (leT_tr _ _ _ yz zx) (leT_tr _ _ _ zx xy); apply: ltn_trans.
rewrite -{s1}Ds -(mkseq_nth x s) !(filter_map, sort_map); congr map.
apply/(@irr_sorted_eq _ lt_lex); rewrite /lt_lex /leN //=.
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: I think so. I'm ok with the renaming.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
> Also, I'm not sure what's the connection to "lexicographic ordering", which I understand as the extension of an order from a type to sequences/words over that type, as done in dictionaries. But maybe that term is ambiguous.

> @chdoc, yes this is the lexicographic ordering on `nat * nat` with respective order relations `leN` and `ltn`, ...

I meant that the following relation can be seen as (a generalization of) lexicographic ordering:
```coq
Definition lexord (T : Type) (leT leT' : rel T) : rel T :=
  [rel x y | leT x y && (leT y x ==> leT' x y)].
```
In the case of that `T` is a product type and `leT` and `leT'` compare its first and second component respectively, `lexord` is the lexicographic ordering of products. Since order structures require `<=%O` to be antisymmetric, this generalization does not make sense in `order.v`.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Done.

commits.author: pi8027
commits.message:
Refactor, reshuffle, and rename sorting lemmas in `path.v`

- Lemmas `sorted_(lt|le)_nth` have been renamed to `sorted_(ltn|leq)_nth`.
- Lemmas `(ltn|leq)_index` have been renamed to `sorted_(ltn|leq)_index` and
  generalized for non-`eqType`s.
- Lemmas `order_path_min`, `path_sortedE`, `subseq_order_path`, `subseq_sorted`,
  `sorted_uniq`, `sorted_eq`, `irr_sorted_eq`, `sorted_(ltn|leq)_nth`, and
  `sorted_(ltn|leq)_index` have been relocated since their proofs are
  independent from `merge` and `sort`.
- The stability proofs for `iota` sequences (`push_stable`, `pop_stable`, and
  `sort_iota_stable`) have been simplified by sorting out their hypotheses and
  by redefining `push_invariant` to include the `sorted` condition. Their main
  result `sort_iota_stable`, formerly a local `Let` to prove `sort_stable`, has
  been turned into a lemma.
- Some stability proofs for general sequences (`sort_stable` and `filter_sort`)
  have also been simplified, of which the former one uses the above
  `sorted_ltn_nth` lemma for a non-`eqType`.

discussion.author: pi8027
discussion.comment:
> This already looks very solid to me. However, I wonder whether using `subseq` rather than explicit masks would simplify things. Put differently, I wonder whether there is additional complexity introduced by not requiring an `eqType`, and whether this is is justified by some application or model.

In general, I would like to make `_in` lemmas general enough to derive their specific counterparts immediately. Since `(homo|mono)_(path|cycle|sorted)` lemmas have not been derived from their `_in` counterparts, this probably does not apply to this PR. But, IMO, this is quite crucial to keep PR #601 as simple as possible, since many existing lemmas which I generalize do not require an `eqType`.

Also, I observed that `homo_sorted_in` generalized in this PR was useful to prove the following lemma (I actually managed to prove it):
```coq
Lemma sort_map_in
      (T : Type) (T' : eqType) (P : {pred T}) (f : T -> T') leT leT' :
  {in P &, antisymmetric (relpre f leT')} ->
  {in P & &, transitive (relpre f leT')} -> {in P &, total leT} ->
  {in P &, {homo f : x y / leT x y >-> leT' x y}} ->
  {in all P, forall s : seq T,
        sort leT' [seq f x | x <- s] = [seq f x | x <- sort leT s]}.
```

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I would have expected this one (and `has_mask` above) to follow from the `subseq (mask m s) s` and monotonicity of `all`. However, this requires some shuffling, so maybe it can be done in a separate PR.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: maybe move the hypothesis up?

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I'm a bit surprised/sad that the lemmas in this section are proved after their more specific counterparts. On the other hand, all lemmas in the `HomoPath` section are already one-liners. So maybe we can keep it as is.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Unfortunately, it breaks `abelian.v`. The arguments `x` and `s` of `order_path_min` should come before `leT_tr`. https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/358#discussion_r295259267

review_discussion.comment:


review_discussion.comment: Done.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Oh, but proving `has_mask` and `all_mask` using the `subseq` lemmas specializes `T` to an `eqType`. I don't think it is a good idea.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
I'm of two minds about this. On the one hand, I agree that one should not require an `eqType` where none is required. On the other hand, I find it deeply unsatisfying to resort to induction just because `mathcomp` defines list membership (and hence list inclusion) only for `eqType`. Using the `In` predicate, whose use I'm really not advocating here, it's not too hard to prove:
```coq
Lemma In_mask x m s : In x (mask m s) -> In x s. 
Lemma In_all a s s' : (forall x, In x s -> In x s') -> all a s' -> all a s.

Lemma all_mask a m s : all a s -> all a (mask m s).
Proof. by apply/In_all => ?; exact: In_mask. Qed.
```
Again, this is not about this specific lemma, this is about the general principle about lists as "sets" or "collections" without equality and how to reason about them. @CohenCyril do you have an opinion on the matter?

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: I think we should open a new issue anyway then.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment:
I'm afraid, but the lemma you removed from this PR was not the only place where the lack of an `eqType` structure makes you resort to induction where one would expect monotonicity to be used. For instance, the last line could be:
```
by apply/(@allP _ _ (y::s)); rewrite /= ?mem_last ?Py.
```
if `T` was an `eqType`. 

@CohenCyril , what's your position on this?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
Until mathcomp introduces support for non decidable membership*, it's perfectly ok not to rely on a lemma involving `mem` to show something that does not involve an `eqType`. If it really matters, it is suggested one goes through `mkseqP` or `mkseq_nth` lemmas to index the biggest list with natural numbers `iota 0 (size the_big_list)`, and hence reduce the reasoning to the `eqType` `nat`, (which is the best we can do when we are not able to distinguish one element from another).

*supporting non decidable predicates (such as `In`) would be a radical modification of mathcomp and could introduce a lot of code duplication if not done properly. But on the other hand it would be extremely useful for mathcomp-analysis, and it could be a good topic of discussion for a mathcomp meeting or rather a working group on the topic.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: It's ok to "duplicate" short proofs.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
However, maybe this proof could start with 
```coq
case: s => [|x s]; first by rewrite mask0.
have [n f {x s}_] := mkseqP x (x :: s); rewrite all_map cycle_map -map_mask.
```

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: I realized the fact that `leT` relates all the elements of `s` if `leT` is transitive and `cycle leT s` holds. So `cycle_(filter|mask)_in` lemmas may not be that useful. Shouldn't we rather remove them for now?

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
BTW you could reuse old material with the following proof, but that would be counterproductive...
```coq
Lemma all_mask T (a : pred T) m s : all a s -> all a (mask m s).
Proof.
case: s => [|x s]; first by rewrite mask0.
have [n f {x s}_] := mkseqP x (x :: s); rewrite -map_mask !all_map.
by move=> /allP fan; apply/allP => x /mem_mask/fan.
Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment: Sure, maybe there should be a proof that `cycle leT s -> allrel leT s` ?

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: Good. Let me do that in another PR since #630 seems useful for it.

review_discussion.author: chdoc
review_discussion.comment: I opened issue #638 to organize the larger discussion on non-decidable membership and I will ignore the issue as it comes to this PR.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: @chdoc Thanks!

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
Ah, I discovered another one-liner!
```suggestion
Lemma all_mask a m s : all a s -> all a (mask m s).
Proof. by apply/contraTT; rewrite -!has_predC; apply: has_mask. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment: I decided to put `all_mask` before `has_mask` and shorten `has_mask` similarly so that we can save one more line.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Proof. by elim: s m => [|x s IHs] [|[] m]//= /andP[ax /IHs->]; rewrite ?ax. Qed.
```

review_discussion.comment: (the induction on `s` changes nothing but I have my own tastes :wink:)

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment:
I'm a bit surprised that this change does not cause any breakage whatsoever. One reason might be that the lemma, regardless of the premise, is too weak to be of much use. I only found one use for this lemma so far, and that was to prove the following strengthening. (I'm including the comment I added when proving this 18 months ago :smile:)
```coq
(** TOTHINK: [#|P| <= #|aT|] would suffice, the other direction is
implied. But the same is true for [inj_card_onto]. *)
Lemma inj_card_onto_pred (aT rT : finType) (f : aT -> rT) (P : pred rT) : 
  injective f -> (forall x, f x \in P) -> #|aT| = #|P| -> {in P, forall y, y \in codom f}.
Proof.
move=> f_inj fP E y yP.
pose rT' := { y : rT | P y}; pose f' (x:aT) : rT' := Sub (f x) (fP x).
have/inj_card_onto f'_inj : injective f' by  move => x1 x2 []; apply: f_inj.
rewrite -[#|P|]card_sig in E; have/mapP[x _ [] ->] := f'_inj E (Sub y yP). 
exact: codom_f. 
Qed.
```
This one I use a handful of times. I guess one could also have a predicate `A` on the argument type and weaken this to {in A&, injective f} and f a homomorphism from A to P.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
@chdoc note that two lemmas were generalized, and the second one `inj_card_bij`, is used slightly more often. I guess one reason no breakage occurs is that every proof solving `#|T| = #|T'|` can solve `#|T| >= #|T'|` just as easily.
As for your variation on `inj_card_onto`, I'd say it would be a nice addition indeed, in a subsequent PR.
I suggest the following statements + proofs (rather than going all the way through `inj_card_onto`):
```coq
Lemma inj_image_eq (aT rT : finType) (f : aT -> rT) 
    (D : {pred aT}) (P : {pred rT}) : 
    {in D &, injective f} -> image f D \subset P -> #|P| <= #|D| ->
  image f D =i P.
Proof.
move=> f_inj fP leP; apply/subset_cardP => //; apply/eqP.
by rewrite eqn_leq subset_leq_card//= (leq_trans leP)// card_in_image.
Qed.

Lemma inj_codom_eq (aT rT : finType) (f : aT -> rT) (P : {pred rT}) : 
  injective f -> codom f \subset P -> #|P| <= #|aT| -> codom f =i P.
Proof. by move=> f_inj; apply/inj_image_eq; apply: in2W. Qed.
```

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment:
> I guess one reason no breakage occurs is that every proof solving `#|T| = #|T'|` can solve `#|T| >= #|T'|` just as easily.

I was a bit worried that there could be places where the the equality is shown by showing `#|T| >= #|T'|` and `#|T| <= #|T'|` separately, possibly duplicating your argument. But neither lemma is used withing mathcomp (outside of fintype), so even if this is the case, it would be of no concern to this PR.

discussion.comment: Remark: `forall x, count_mem x s1 <= count_mem x s2` can be seen as a non-symmetric version of `perm_eq` (conversely, `perm_eq` is the symmetric closure of it). Defining a boolean relation for this and refactoring the `perm_eq` theory using it can probably be useful, but depending on its applications.

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
The converse of this lemma also holds, and both directions hold for each `x : T`. So it should probably be something like this:
```coq
Lemma leq_uniq_countP x s1 s2 : uniq s1 ->
  reflect (x \in s1 -> x \in s2) (count_mem x s1 <= count_mem x s2).
Proof.
move/count_uniq_mem->; case: (boolP (_ \in _)) => //= _; last by constructor.
by rewrite -has_pred1 has_count; apply: (iffP idP) => //; apply.
Qed.
```
Since it aims to bridge the gap between `count_maskP` and `subset_maskP`, it is also fine to replace the last implication with `<->`.

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril
review_discussion.comment:
for composition to be possible we should have your lemma and mine, untouched.

blindfix!

```suggestion
Lemma leq_uniq_countP x s1 s2 : uniq s1 ->
  reflect (x \in s1 -> x \in s2) (count_mem x s1 <= count_mem x s2).
Proof.
move/count_uniq_mem->; case: (boolP (_ \in _)) => //= _; last by constructor.
by rewrite -has_pred1 has_count; apply: (iffP idP) => //; apply.
Qed.

Lemma leq_uniq_count s1 s2 : uniq s1 -> {subset s1 <= s2} ->
  (forall x, count_mem x s1 <= count_mem x s2).
Proof. by move=> s1_uniq s1_s2 x; apply/leq_uniq_countP/s1_s2. Qed.
```

commits.author: CohenCyril
commits.message:
Adding some theory for `rem` and generalizing `subset_maskP`

- Added helper lemmas about `rem`: `rem_cons` (to control unfolding),
  `remE`, `count_rem`, `count_mem_rem`, and `subseq_mem`.
  (New lemma `drop_index` briges the gap between `cat_take_drop` and `remE`).
- `subset_maskP`, which was not released yet is generalized with
  hypothesis `(forall x, count_mem x s1 <= count_mem x s2)`, instead of
  `uniq s1` and `{subset s1 <= s2}`, the previous behaviour can be
  restored with helper lemma `leq_uniq_count`
- Its trivial consequence `subset_subseqP` has been added too.

discussion.author: erikmd
discussion.comment:
Thanks @chdoc, so here is the wrap-up :)

## The "overall aim" is two-fold:

1. ensure that the mathcomp.dev image obtained by

    ```
    docker pull mathcomp/mathcomp-dev:coq-dev
    ```
    always brings **the latest coq master** (and not just the last nightly build).

2. ensure that beyond this automatic deployment, math-comp's CI still runs the test-suite on coq-dev (to **detect regressions**).

Note that point 2. is related to the recent CI enhancement done in @gares' PR https://github.com/math-comp/math-comp/pull/433

Point 1. is not directly performed by this PR #614, but this PR is a necessary ingredient for fully implementing the new architecture of the coq/docker-coq/docker-mathcomp CI/CD that we discussed recently with @Zimmi48, to get rid of the "nightly-build limitation" of docker images of coq & mathcomp.

### To sum up, the old architecture was as follows:

![2020-11_math-comp-before-pr614](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10367254/98430180-0ed16600-20ac-11eb-8977-e45c3bba8f49.png)

### And the new architecture is as follows:

![2020-11_math-comp-using-pr614](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10367254/98430202-45a77c00-20ac-11eb-91d5-080da46bd32b.png)

## Regarding the positioning of this PR #614:

As shown above in the figures, a key change is that the automatically triggered pipeline in math-comp CI from coq-community CI **cannot be a scheduled pipeline**. Hence the use of a special environment variable `CRON_MODE`.

This is the core change of this PR.

It also does one refactoring and a small fix :

1. Use only:refs, except:refs (no change intended, but replace old GitLab syntax with GitLab 10.0+ syntax)

2. Fix (to have better clarity in the GitLab CI deployment browser) the environment deployment names related to the `deploy` stage jobs for the `master` protected branch (see the commit message for more details if need be).

## Additional details

FYI I've just tested the behavior of this PR on a temporary separate repo: https://gitlab.com/erikmd/math-comp-ci-preflight

The main thing that had to be checked was *whether the created stages and jobs were OK* in the following three configurations:

* pr-0 (non-protected branch)  **full** build+test [(url)](https://gitlab.com/erikmd/math-comp-ci-preflight/-/pipelines/213003576)
* master (protected branch), regular pipeline  **full** build+deploy+test [(url)](https://gitlab.com/erikmd/math-comp-ci-preflight/-/pipelines/213003062)
* master (protected branch), regular pipeline triggered with CRON_MODE  **coq-dev** build+deploy+test [(url)](https://gitlab.com/erikmd/math-comp-ci-preflight/-/pipelines/213003632)

commits.author: erikmd
commits.message:
feat: Update only/except rules

* Use only:refs, except:refs (available since GitLab 10.0)

* Add except:variables/($CRON_MODE == "nightly")
  so coqbot can trigger the jobs currently chosen for scheduled pipelines,
  with a regular pipeline on master with variable CRON_MODE := nightly

* Overall aim: rebuild coqorg/coq:dev & mathcomp/mathcomp-dev:coq-dev
  on GitLab CI after each successful update of coq.dev, using coqbot.

commits.author: erikmd
commits.message:
fix: Deploy each image w.r.t. a separate GitLab CI environment name

to fully benefit from the "forward_deployment_failure" feature
cf. https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/deployment_safety.html#skip-outdated-deployment-jobs

Remark on environment names:
> Caution: Some characters are not allowed in environment names. Use
> only letters, numbers, spaces, and '-', '_', '/', '{', '}', or '.'.
> Also, it must not start nor end with '/'.
cf. https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/index.html

```coq
Lemma iter_addr n (m : V) p : iter n (+%R m) p = m *+ n + p.

```

The following alternative seems to be slightly general:
```suggestion
Lemma in_mask x m s :
  uniq s -> x \in mask m s = (x \in s) && nth false m (index x s).
Proof.
elim: s m => [|y s IHs] [|[] m]//= /andP[yNs ?]; rewrite ?in_cons ?IHs //=;
by have [->|neq_xy] //= := eqVneq; rewrite ?andbF // (negPf yNs).
Qed.
```

```suggestion
Lemma cons_subseq s1 s2 x : subseq (x :: s1) s2 -> subseq s1 s2.
Proof. exact/subseq_trans/subseq_cons. Qed.
```

review_discussion.author: pi8027
review_discussion.comment:
```suggestion
Lemma undup_subseq s : subseq (undup s) s.
Proof.
elim: s => //= x s; case: (_ \in _); last by rewrite eqxx.
by case: (undup s) => //= y u; case: (_ == _) => //=; apply: cons_subseq.
Qed.
```


discussion.author: herbelin
discussion.comment: For the record, it seems that the change around `iota_add` -> `iotaD` breaks the compilation of Coquelicot on Coq CI (e.g. [here](https://gitlab.com/coq/coq/-/jobs/822996322)). Something related to `hide` not propagating the scopes of `iota_add`. In particular, `(ssreflect.Deprecation.hide (fun iota_add iotaD => _) iotaD (m - n) n)` interprets `m - n` in the ambiant stack of scopes (thus in `R_scope` in the case of Coquelicot) while it is expected to be interpreted in `nat_scope`.

discussion.author: CohenCyril
discussion.comment:
> @CohenCyril I chose `_pivot` for the `s1 ++ x :: s2` pattern, but I am open to suggestions. I would favor this pattern over `rcons s1 x ++ s2`, because the former arises naturally when using `rot_to_arc` (`x` being the beginning of the second arc).

All right, I never noticed this before, this is a bit unfortunate since `splitP` chooses the other pattern :disappointed:

discussion.author: chdoc
discussion.comment: Well, just ran a count on my graph-theory development and I have about the same number of uses of `path.splitP` (if one imports `all_ssreflect`, `splitP` ends up being the one for ordinals) and of `splitPr`. The former is more useful when dealing with paths, where one usually cares about the last element, so `splitP` allows rewriting with `last_rcons`. The latter is more useful when dealing with arcs, where the "end" of the arc is actually part of the other arc (i.e, `arc s x y` contains `x` but not `y`).

review_discussion.author: CohenCyril

```suggestion
Lemma rev_mask m s : size m = size s -> rev (mask m s) = mask (rev m) (rev s).
Proof.
move: m s; apply: seq_ind2 => //= b x m s eq_size_sm IH.
by case: b; rewrite !rev_cons mask_rcons ?IH ?size_rev// (cats1, cats0).
Qed.
```
provided you also add
```coq
Lemma mask_rcons b m x s : size m = size s ->
  mask (rcons m b) (rcons s x) = mask m s ++ nseq b x.
Proof. by move=> ms; rewrite -!cats1 mask_cat//; case: b. Qed.
```
